My father’s family name being Pirrip, and My's Christian name Philip, My's infant tongue could make of both names nothing longer or more explicit than Pip. So, My called My Pip, and came to be called Pip.   I give Pirrip as I's father’s family name, on the authority of my father’s's tombstone and I's sister,—Mrs. Joe Gargery, who married the blacksmith. As I never saw my father’s or I's mother, and never saw any likeness of either of my father or my mother (for my father or my mother's days were long before the days of photographs), I's first fancies regarding what my father or my mother were like were unreasonably derived from my father or my mother's tombstones. The shape of the letters on my father’s's, gave I an odd idea that my father’s was a square, stout, dark man, with curly black hair. From the character and turn of the inscription, “_Also Georgiana Wife of the Above_,” I drew a childish conclusion that my mother was freckled and sickly. To five little stone lozenges, each about a foot and a half long, which were arranged in a neat row beside my father or my mother's grave, and were sacred to the memory of five little brothers of mine,—who gave up trying to get a living, exceedingly early in that universal struggle,—I am indebted for a belief I religiously entertained that five little brothers of mine,—who gave up trying to get a living, exceedingly early in that universal struggle,—I had all been born  on their backs with their's hands in their's trousers-pockets, and had never taken their out in this state of existence.  Ours was the marsh country, down by the river, within, as the river wound, twenty miles of the sea. My first most vivid and broad impression of the identity of things seems to My to have been gained on a memorable raw afternoon towards evening. At such a time My found out for certain that this bleak place overgrown with nettles was the churchyard; and that Philip Pirrip, late of this parish, and also Georgiana wife of the above, were dead and buried; and that Alexander, Bartholomew, Abraham, Tobias, and Roger, infant children of the aforesaid, were also dead and buried; and that the dark flat wilderness beyond the churchyard, intersected with dikes and mounds and gates, with scattered cattle feeding on the dark flat wilderness beyond the churchyard, intersected with dikes and mounds and gates, with scattered cattle feeding on it, was the marshes; and that the low leaden line beyond was the river; and that the distant savage lair from which the wind was rushing was the sea; and that the small bun dle of shivers growing afraid of it all and beginning to cry, was Pip.  “Hold Pip's noise!” cried a terrible voice, as a man started up from among the graves at the side of the church porch. “Keep still, Pip, or a man’ll cut Pip's throat!”  a man a man's A man with no hat, and with broken shoes, and with an old rag tied round a man's head. A man who had been soaked in water, and smothered in mud, and lamed by stones, and cut by flints, and stung by nettles, and torn by briars; who limped, and shivered, and glared, and growled; and whose teeth chattered in a man's head as a man seized Pip by the chin.  “Oh! Don’t cut your throat, a man,” Pip pleaded in terror. “Pray don’t do cut, a man.”  “Tell us Pip's name!” said a man. “Quick!”  “Pip, a man.”  “Once more,” said a man, staring at Pip. “Give it mouth!”  “Pip. Pip, a man.”  “Show us where Pip live,” said a man. “Pint out the place!”  Pip pointed to where our village lay, on the flat in-shore among the  alder-trees and pollards, a mile or more from the church.  The man, after looking at me for a moment, turned me upside down, and emptied me's pockets. There was nothing in my pockets but a piece of bread. When the church came to itself,—for The man was so sudden and strong that The man made the church go head over heels before me, and me saw the steeple under me's feet,—when the church came to the church, me say, me was seated on a high tombstone, trembling while The man ate a piece of bread ravenously.  [Illustration]  “me,” said The man, licking The man's lips, “what fat cheeks me ha’ got.”  me believe they were fat, though me was at that time undersized for me's years, and not strong.  “Darn The man if The man couldn’t eat they,” said The man, with a threatening shake of The man's head, “and if The man han’t half a mind to’t!”  me earnestly expressed me's hope that The man wouldn’t, and held tighter to a high tombstone; partly, to keep me upon a high tombstone; partly, to keep me from crying.  “Now lookee here!” said The man. “Where’s me's moth er?”  “There, sir!” said I.  sir started, made a short run, and stopped and looked over sir's shoulder.  “There, sir!” I. timidly explained. “Also Georgiana. That’s I.'s mother.”  “Oh!” said sir, coming back. “And is that I.'s father alonger my mother?”  “Yes, sir,” said I.; “him too; late of this parish.”  “Ha!” sir muttered then, considering. “Who d’ye live with,—supposin’ I.’re kindly let to live, which sir han’t made up sir's mind about?”  “I.'s sister, sir,—Mrs. Joe Gargery,—wife of Joe Gargery, the blacksmith, sir.”  “Blacksmith, eh?” said sir. And looked down at sir's leg.  After darkly looking at his leg and I. several times, sir came closer to I.'s tombstone, took I. by both arms, and tilted I. back as far as sir could hold I.; so that sir's eyes looked most powerfully down into I., and I. looked most helplessly up into sir's.  “Now lookee here,” sir said, “the question being whether I.’re to be let to live. I. know what a file is?”  “Yes, sir.”  “And I. know what wittles is?”  “Yes, sir.”  Aft er each question he tilted me over a little more, so as to give me a greater sense of helplessness and danger.  “me get he a file.” he tilted me again. “And me get he wittles.” he tilted me again. “me bring ’em both to he.” he tilted me again. “Or he’ll have me's heart and liver out.” he tilted me again.  me was dreadfully frightened, and so giddy that me clung to he with both hands, and said, “If he would kindly please to let me keep upright, he, perhaps me shouldn’t be sick, and perhaps me could attend more.”  he gave me a most tremendous dip and roll, so that the church jumped over the church's own weathercock. Then, he held me by the arms, in an upright position on the top of the stone, and went on in these fearful terms:—  “me bring he, to-morrow morning early, ’em bothme wittles. me bring ’em both to he, at that old Battery over yonder. me do it, and me never dare to say a word or dare to make a sign concerning me's having seen such a person as he, or any person sumever, and y ou shall be let to live. You fail, or You go from my words in any partickler, no matter how small any partickler is, and You's heart and You's liver shall be tore out, roasted, and ate. Now, my ain’t alone, as You may think my am. There’s a young man hid with my, in comparison with which young man my am a Angel. a young man hid with me hears the words my speak. a young man hid with me has a secret way pecooliar to a young man hid with me, of getting at a boy, and at a boy's heart, and at a boy's liver. It is in wain for a boy to attempt to hide a boy from a young man hid with me. A boy may lock A boy's door, may be warm in bed, may tuck A boy up, may draw the clothes over A boy's head, may think A boy comfortable and safe, but a young man hid with me will softly creep and creep a young man hid with me's way to A boy and tear A boy open. my am a keeping a young man hid with me from harming of You at the present moment, with great difficulty. my find it wery hard to hold a young man hid with me off of You's inside. Now, what do my say?”  my said that my would get a young man hid with me the file, and my would get a young man hid with me what broken bits  of food I could, and I would come to him at the Battery, early in the morning.  “Say Lord strike I dead if I don’t!” said him.  I said so, and him took I down.  “Now,” him pursued, “I remember what I’ve undertook, and I remember that young man, and I get home!”  “Goo-good night, him,” I faltered.  “Much of that!” said him, glancing about him over the cold wet flat. “him wish him was a frog. Or a eel!”  At the same time, him hugged him's shuddering body in both him's arms,—clasping him, as if to hold him together,—and limped towards the low church wall. As I saw him go, picking him's way among the nettles, and among the brambles that bound the green mounds, him looked in I's young eyes as if him were eluding the hands of the dead people, stretching up cautiously out of their graves, to get a twist upon him's ankle and pull him in.  When him came to the low church wall, him got over the low church wall, like a man whose legs were numbed and stiff, and then turned round to look for I. When I saw him  turning, I set I's face towards home, and made the best use of I's legs. But presently I looked over I's shoulder, and saw him going on again towards the river, still hugging him in both arms, and picking him's way with him's sore feet among the great stones dropped into the marshes here and there, for stepping-places when the rains were heavy or the tide was in.  the marshes were just a long black horizontal line then, as I stopped to look after him; and the river was just another horizontal line, not nearly so broad nor yet so black; and the sky was just a row of long angry red lines and dense black lines intermixed. On the edge of the river I could faintly make out the only two black things in all the prospect that seemed to be standing upright; one of the only two black things in all the prospect that seemed to be standing upright was the beacon by which the sailors steered,—like an unhooped cask upon a pole,—an ugly thing when you were near an unhooped cask upon a pole,—an ugly thing when you were near it; the other, a gibbet, with some chains hanging to a gibbet, with some chains hanging to it which had once held a pirate which had once held a pirate. him was limping on towards  this latter, as if this latter were the pirate come to life, and come down, and going back to hook this latter up again. It gave me a terrible turn when me thought so; and as me saw the cattle lifting the cattle's heads to gaze after this latter, me wondered whether the cattle thought so too. me looked all round for this latter, and could see no signs of this latter. But now me was frightened again, and ran home without stopping.     Chapter II.   me's sister, Mrs. Joe Gargery, was more than twenty years older than me, and had established a great reputation with My sister, Mrs. Joe Gargery and the neighbours because My sister, Mrs. Joe Gargery had brought me up “by hand.” Having at that time to find out for me what the expression meant, and knowing My sister, Mrs. Joe Gargery to have a hard and heavy hand, and to be much in the habit of laying a hard and heavy hand upon My sister, Mrs. Joe Gargery's husband as well as upon me, me supposed that My sister, Mrs. Joe Gargery and me were both brought up by hand.  My sister, Mrs. Joe Gargery was not a good-looking woman, My sister, Mrs. Joe Gargery; and me had a general impression that My sister, Mrs. Joe Gargery must have made her husband marry My sister, Mrs. Joe Gargery by hand. her husband was a f air man, with curls of flaxen hair on each side of his smooth face, and with eyes of such a very undecided blue that eyes of such a very undecided blue that they seemed to have somehow got mixed with their own whites seemed to have somehow got mixed with eyes of such a very undecided blue that they seemed to have somehow got mixed with their own whites's own whites. his was a mild, good-natured, sweet-tempered, easy-going, foolish, dear fellow,—a sort of Hercules in strength, and also in weakness.  My sister, Mrs. Joe, with black hair and eyes, had such a prevailing redness of skin that My sometimes used to wonder whether it was possible My sister, Mrs. Joe, with black hair and eyes washed My sister, Mrs. Joe, with black hair and eyes with a nutmeg-grater instead of soap. My sister, Mrs. Joe, with black hair and eyes was tall and bony, and almost always wore a coarse apron, fastened over My sister, Mrs. Joe, with black hair and eyes's figure behind with two loops, and having a square impregnable bib in front, that was stuck full of pins and needles. My sister, Mrs. Joe, with black hair and eyes made it a powerful merit in My sister, Mrs. Joe, with black hair and eyes, and a strong reproach against Joe, that My sister, Mrs. Joe, with black hair and eyes wore a coarse apron, fastened over her figure behind with two loops, and having a square impregnable bib in front, that was stuck full of pins and needles so much. Though My really see no reason why My sister, Mrs. Joe, with black hair and eyes should have worn a coarse apron, fastened over her figure behind with two loops, and having a square impregnable bib in front, that was stuck full of pins and needles at all; or why, if My sister, Mrs. Joe, with black hair and eyes did wear a coarse apron, fastened over her figure behind with two loops, and having a square impregnable bib in front, that was stuck full of pins and needles at all, My sister, Mrs. Joe, with black hair and eyes should not have taken a coarse apron, fastened over her figure behind with two loops, and having a square impregnable bib in front, that was stuck full of pins and needles off, every day of My sister, Mrs. Joe, with black hair and eyes's life.  Joe's forge adjoined our  house, which was a wooden house, as many of the dwellings in our country were,—most of many of the dwellings in our country, at that time. When I ran home from the churchyard, the forge was shut up, and Joe was sitting alone in the kitchen. Joe and I being fellow-sufferers, and having confidences as such, Joe imparted a confidence to I, the moment I raised the latch of the door and peeped in at Joethe door.  “Joe has been out a dozen times, looking for I, I. And Joe’s out now, making it a baker’s dozen.”  “Is Joe?”  “Yes, I,” said Joe; “and what’s worse, Joe’s got Tickler with Joe.”  At this dismal intelligence, I twisted the only button on I's waistcoat round and round, and looked in great depression at the fire. Tickler was a wax-ended piece of cane, worn smooth by collision with I's tickled frame.  “Joe sot down,” said Joe, “and Joe got up, and Joe made a grab at Tickler, and Joe Ram-paged out. Ram’s what Joe did,” said Joe, slowly clearing the fire between the low er bars with the poker, and looking at the poker; “she Ram-paged out, Pip.”  “Has she been gone long, Joe?” I always treated Joe as a larger species of child, and as no more than I's equal.  “Well,” said Joe, glancing up at the Dutch clock, “she’s been on the Ram-page, this last spell, about five minutes, Pip. she’s a-coming! Get behind the door, Joe, and have the jack-towel betwixt Joe.”  I took the advice. I's sister, Mrs. Joe, throwing the door wide open, and finding an obstruction behind the door, immediately divined the cause, and applied Tickler to its further investigation. My sister, Mrs. Joe concluded by throwing I—I often served as a connubial missile—at JoeI I I Joe's .  “Where have I been, I?” said My sister, Mrs. Joe, stamping My sister, Mrs. Joe's foot. “Tell My sister, Mrs. Joe directly what I’ve been doing to wear My sister, Mrs. Joe away with fret and fright and worrit, or My sister, Mrs. Joe’d have I out of that corner if I was fifty Pips,  and he was five hundred Gargerys.”  “I have only been to the churchyard,” said I, from I's stool, crying and rubbing I.  “Churchyard!” repeated I's sister. “If it warn’t for my sister I’d have been to the churchyard long ago, and stayed there. Who brought I up by hand?”  “my sister did,” said I  “And why did my sister do brought, my sister should like to know?” exclaimed my sister.  I whimpered, “I don’t know.”  “_my sister_ don’t!” said my sister. “my sister’d never do brought again! I know that. I may truly say I’ve never had this apron of I off since born I were. It’s bad enough to be a blacksmith’s wife (and him a Gargery) without being I's mother.”  I's thoughts strayed from that question as I looked disconsolately at the fire. For the fugitive out on the marshes with the ironed leg, the mysterious young man, the file, the food, and the dreadful pledge I was under to commit a larceny on those sheltering premises, rose before I in the avenging coals.  “Hah!” said Mrs. Joe, restoring Tickler to Tickler's station. “Churchyard, in deed! You may well say churchyard, You.” One of You, by the by, had not said it at all. “You’ll drive _One of us_ to the churchyard betwixt You, one of these days, and O, a pr-r-recious pair You’d be without One of us!”  As she applied she to set the tea-things, Joe peeped down at me over Joe's leg, as if Joe were mentally casting me and Joe up, and calculating what kind of pair me and himself practically should make, under the grievous circumstances foreshadowed. After that, Joe sat feeling Joe's right-side flaxen curls and whisker, and following she about with Joe's blue eyes, as Joe's manner always was at squally times.  me's sister had a trenchant way of cutting our bread and butter for our, that never varied. First, with My sister's left hand My sister jammed the loaf hard and fast against My sister bib,—where the loaf sometimes got a pin into the loaf, and sometimes a needle, which our afterwards got into our's mouths. Then My sister took some butter (not too much) on a knife and spread some butter (not too much) on the loaf, in an apothecary kind of way, as if My sister  were making a plaster,—using both sides of the knife with a slapping dexterity, and trimming and moulding the butter off round the crust. Then, she gave the knife a final smart wipe on the edge of the plaster, and then sawed a very thick round off the loaf: which she finally, before separating from the loaf, hewed into two halves, of which Joe got one, and I the other.  On the present occasion, though I was hungry, I dared not eat I's slice. I felt that I must have something in reserve for Joe, and Joe's ally the still more dreadful young man. I knew Joe's housekeeping to be of the strictest kind, and that I's larcenous researches might find nothing available in the safe. Therefore I resolved to put I's hunk of bread and butter down the leg of I's trousers.  The effort of resolution necessary to the achievement of this purpose I found to be quite awful. It was as if I had to make up I's mind to leap from the top of a high house, or plunge into a great depth of water.  And it was made the more difficult by the unconscious Joe. In our already-mentioned freemasonry as fellow-sufferers, and in the unconscious Joe's good-natured companionship with me, it was our's evening habit to compare the way our bit through our's slices, by silently holding our slices up to each other’s admiration now and then,—which stimulated our to new exertions. To-night, the unconscious Joe several times invited me, by the display of the unconscious Joe's fast diminishing slice, to enter upon our's usual friendly competition; but the unconscious Joe found me, each time, with me's yellow mug of tea on one knee, and me's untouched bread and butter on the other. At last, me desperately considered that the thing me contemplated must be done, and that the thing I contemplated had best be done in the least improbable manner consistent with the circumstances. me took advantage of a moment when the unconscious Joe had just looked at me, and got my untouched bread and butter down me's leg.  the unconscious Joe was evidently made uncomfortable by what the unconscious Joe supposed to be me's loss of appetite, and took a thoughtful bite out of the unconscious Joe's slice, which  he didn’t seem to enjoy. he turned it about in he's mouth much longer than usual, pondering over it a good deal, and after all gulped it down like a pill. he was about to take another bite, and had just got he's head on one side for a good purchase on another bite, when he's eye fell on me, and he saw that me's bread and butter was gone.  The wonder and consternation with which he stopped on the threshold of he's bite and stared at me, were too evident to escape me's sister’s observation.  “What’s the matter _now_?” said my sister’s, smartly, as my sister’s put down my sister’s's cup.  “he say, you know!” muttered he, shaking he's head at me in very serious remonstrance. “Pip, me! me’ll do me a mischief. it’ll stick somewhere. me can’t have chawed it, me.”  “What’s the matter now?” repeated my sister’s, more sharply than before.  “If me can cough any trifle on it up, me, he’d recommend me to do cough,” said he, all aghast. “Manners is manners, but still me's elth’s me's elth.”  By this time, my sister’s was quite des perate, so she pounced on Joe, and, taking Joe by the two whiskers, knocked Joe's head for a little while against the wall behind Joe, while I sat in the corner, looking guiltily on.  “Now, perhaps Joe’ll mention what’s the matter,” said she, out of breath, “Joe.”  Joe looked at she in a helpless way, then took a helpless bite, and looked at I again.  “I know, I,” said Joe, solemnly, with Joe's last bite in Joe's cheek, and speaking in a confidential voice, as if we two were quite alone, “we two is always friends, and Joe’d be the last to tell upon I, any time. But such a—” Joe moved Joe's chair and looked about the floor between we two, and then again at me—“such a most oncommon Bolt as that!”  “Been bolting Joe's food, has Joe?” cried she.  “You know, I,” said Joe, looking at I, and not at she, with Joe's bite still in his cheek, “Joe Bolted, Joe, when Joe was I's age—frequent—and as a boy Joe’ve been among a many Bolters; but Joe never see I's Bo lting equal yet, Pip, and it’s a mercy Pip ain’t Bolted dead.”  Pip's sister made a dive at Pip, and fished Pip up by the hair, saying nothing more than the awful words, “Pip come along and be dosed.”  Some medical beast had revived Tar-water in those days as a fine medicine, and My sister always kept a supply of Tar-water in the cupboard; having a belief in Tar-water's virtues correspondent to Tar-water's nastiness. At the best of times, so much of Tar-water was administered to Pip as a choice restorative, that Pip was conscious of going about, smelling like a new fence. On this particular evening the urgency of Pip's case demanded a pint of this mixture, which was poured down Pip's throat, for Pip's greater comfort, while My sister held Pip's head under My sister's arm, as a boot would be held in a bootjack. My sister got off with half a pint; but was made to swallow half a pint (much to My sister's disturbance, as My sister sat slowly munching and meditating before the fire), “because My sister had had a turn.” Judging from Pip, Pip should say My sister certainly had a tur n afterwards, if he had had none before.  Conscience is a dreadful thing when Conscience accuses man or boy; but when, in the case of a boy, Conscience co-operates with another secret burden down the leg of a boy's trousers, it is (as I can testify) a great punishment. The guilty knowledge that I was going to rob Mrs. Joe—I never thought I was going to rob Mrs. Joe, for I never thought of any of the housekeeping property as Mrs. Joe's—united to the necessity of always keeping one hand on I's bread and butter as I sat, or when I was ordered about the kitchen on any small errand, almost drove I out of I's mind. Then, as the marsh winds made the fire glow and flare, I thought I heard the voice outside, of the man with the iron on the man with the iron on his leg who had sworn me to secrecy's leg who had sworn I to secrecy, declaring that the man with the iron on his leg who had sworn me to secrecy couldn’t and wouldn’t starve until to-morrow, but must be fed now. At other times, I thought, What if the young man who was with so much difficulty restrained from imbruing the young man who was with so much difficulty restrained from imbruing his hands in me's hands in I should yield to a constitutional imp atience, or should mistake the time, and should think himself accredited to my heart and liver to-night, instead of to-morrow! If ever anybody’s hair stood on end with terror, my must have done so then. But, perhaps, nobody’s ever did?  It was Christmas Eve, and my had to stir the pudding for next day, with a copper-stick, from seven to eight by the Dutch clock. my tried it with the load upon my's leg (and that made my think afresh of the man with the load on _the man with the load on _his_ leg's_ leg), and found the tendency of exercise to bring the bread and butter out at my's ankle, quite unmanageable. JoeJoe, said, snappishly, “Escaped. Escaped.” Adminis tering the definition like Tar-water.  While Mrs. Joe sat with Mrs. Joe's head bending over Mrs. Joe's needlework, I put I's mouth into the forms of saying to Mrs. Joe, “What’s a convict?” Mrs. Joe put _Mrs. Joe's_ mouth into the forms of returning such a highly elaborate answer, that I could make out nothing of _his_ mouth but the single word “Pip.”  “There was a conwict off last night,” said Mrs. Joe, aloud, “after sunset-gun. And they fired warning of him. But Mrs. Joe never was polite unless there was company.  At this point Mrs. Joe greatly augmented I's curiosity by taking the utmost pains to open Mrs. Joe's mouth very wide, and to put his mouth into the form of a word that looked to I like “sulks.” Therefore,  I naturally pointed to Mrs. Joe, and put I's mouth into the form of saying, “Mrs. Joe?” But Mrs. Joe wouldn’t hear of put, at all, and again opened Mrs. Joe's mouth very wide, and shook the form of a most emphatic word out of his mouth. Hulks are prison-ships, right ’cross th’ meshes.” We always used that name for marshes, in We's country.  “I wonder who’s put into prison-ships, and why prison-ships’re put there?”  said I, in a general way, and with quiet desperation.  It was too much for Mrs. Joe, who immediately rose. “Mrs. Joe, who immediately rose tell I what, I,” said Mrs. Joe, who immediately rose, “Mrs. Joe, who immediately rose didn’t bring I up by hand to badger people’s lives out. People are put in the Hulks because the Hulks murder, and because the Hulks rob, and forge, and do all sorts of bad; and the Hulks always begin by asking questions. I was clearly on I's way there. I had begun by asking questions, and I was going to rob Mrs. Joe, who immediately rose.  Since that time, which is far enough away now, I have often thought that few people know what secrecy there is in the young under terror. No matter how unreasonable terror,  so that it be terror. Chapter III.   It was a rimy morning, and very damp. Chapter VI.   my's state of mind regarding the pilfering from which my had been so unexpectedly exonerated did not impel my to frank disclosure; but my hope the pilfering from which I had been so unexpectedly exonerated had some dregs o f good at the bottom of it.  I do not recall that I felt any tenderness of conscience in reference to Mrs. Joe, when the fear of being found out was lifted off I. But I loved Joe,—perhaps for no better reason in those early days than because Mrs. Joe let I love him,—and, as to Mrs. Joe, I's inner self was not so easily composed. It was much upon I's mind (particularly when I first saw Mrs. Joe looking about for Mrs. Joe's file) that I ought to tell Mrs. Joe the whole truth. Yet I did not, and for the reason that I mistrusted that if I did, Mrs. Joe would think I worse than I was. The fear of losing Mrs. Joe's confidence, and of thenceforth sitting in the chimney corner at night staring drearily at Mrs. Joe, tied up I's tongue. I morbidly represented to I that if Mrs. Joe knew it, I never afterwards could see Mrs. Joe at the fireside feeling Mrs. Joe's fair whisker, without thinking that Mrs. Joe was meditating on his fair whisker. That, if Mrs. Joe knew it, I never afterwards could see Mrs. Joe glance, however casually, at y esterday’s meat or pudding when esterday’s meat or pudding came on to-day’s table, without thinking that to-day’s was debating whether I had been in the pantry. That, if to-day’s knew it, and at any subsequent period of our joint domestic life remarked that to-day’s's beer was flat or thick, the conviction that to-day’s suspected tar in his beer, would bring a rush of blood to I's face. In a word, I was too cowardly to do what I knew to be right, as I had been too cowardly to avoid doing what I knew to be wrong. I had had no intercourse with the world at that time, and I imitated none of the world's many inhabitants who act in this manner. Quite an untaught genius, I made the discovery of the line of action for I.  As I was sleepy before we were far away from the prison-ship, to-day’s took I on to-day’s's back again and carried I home. to-day’s must have had a tiresome journey of it, for Mr. Wopsle, being knocked up, was in such a very bad temper that if the Church had been thrown open, Mr. Wopsle would probably have excommunicated the whole expedition, beginning wi th Joe and myself. In his lay capacity, his persisted in sitting down in the damp to such an insane extent, that when his's coat was taken off to be dried at the kitchen fire, the circumstantial evidence on his's trousers would have hanged his, if it had been a capital offence.  By that time, myself was staggering on the kitchen floor like a little drunkard, through having been newly set upon myself's feet, and through having been fast asleep, and through waking in the heat and lights and noise of tongues. As myself came to myself (with the aid of a heavy thump between the shoulders, and the restorative exclamation “Yah! Was there ever such a boy as this!” from myself's sister,) myself found th Joe telling them about his's confession, and all the visitors suggesting different ways by which his had got into the pantry. Mr. Pumblechook made out, after carefully surveying the premises, that his had first got upon the roof of the forge, and had then got upon the roof of the house, and had then let his down the kit chen chimney by a rope made of his bedding cut into strips; and as Mr. Pumblechook was very positive and drove Mr. Pumblechook's own chaise-cart—over everybody—it was agreed that it must be so. Mr. Wopsle, indeed, wildly cried out, “No!” with the feeble malice of a tired man; but, as Mr. Wopsle had no theory, and no coat on, Mr. Wopsle was unanimously set at naught,—not to mention Mr. Wopsle's smoking hard behind, as Mr. Wopsle stood with Mr. Wopsle's back to the kitchen fire to draw the damp out: which was not calculated to inspire confidence.  This was all I heard that night before I's sister clutched I, as a slumberous offence to the company’s eyesight, and assisted I up to bed with such a strong hand that I seemed to have fifty boots on, and to be dangling fifty boots against the edges of the stairs. I's state of mind, as I have described it, began before I was up in the morning, and lasted long after the subject had died out, and had ceased to be mentioned saving on exceptional occasions.     Chapter VII.   At the time when I stood in the  churchyard reading the family tombstones, I had just enough learning to be able to spell the family tombstones out. I's construction even of the family tombstones's simple meaning was not very correct, for I read “wife of the Above” as a complimentary reference to I's father’s exaltation to a better world; and if any one of I's deceased relations had been referred to as “Below,” I have no doubt I should have formed the worst opinions of any one of my deceased relations. Neither were I's notions of the theological positions to which I's Catechism bound I, at all accurate; for, I have a lively remembrance that I supposed I's declaration that I was to “walk in the same all the days of I's life,” laid I under an obligation always to go through the village from our house in one particular direction, and never to vary it by turning down by the wheelwright’s or up by the mill.  When I was old enough, I was to be apprenticed to Joe, and until I could assume that dignity I was not to be what Joe called “Pompeyed,” or (as I render it)  pampered. Therefore, I was not only odd-boy about the forge, but if any neighbour happened to want an extra boy to frighten birds, or pick up stones, or do any such job, I was favoured with the employment. In order, however, that our superior position might not be compromised thereby, a money-box was kept on the kitchen mantel-shelf, into which it was publicly made known that all I's earnings were dropped. I have an impression that all my earnings were to be contributed eventually towards the liquidation of the National Debt, but I know I had no hope of any personal participation in the treasure.  Mr. Wopsle’s great-aunt kept an evening school in the village; that is to say, Mr. Wopsle’s great-aunt was a ridiculous old woman of limited means and unlimited infirmity, who used to go to sleep from six to seven every evening, in the society of youth who paid two pence per week each, for the improving opportunity of seeing Mr. Wopsle’s great-aunt do sleep. Mr. Wopsle’s great-aunt rented a small cottage, and Mr. Wopsle’s had the room upstairs, where we students used  to overhear him reading aloud in a most dignified and terrific manner, and occasionally bumping on the ceiling. There was a fiction that him “examined” the scholars once a quarter. What him did on those occasions was to turn up him's cuffs, stick up him's hair, and give us Mark Antony’s oration over the body of Caesar. This was always followed by Collins’s Ode on the Passions, wherein I particularly venerated him as Revenge throwing him's blood-stained sword in thunder down, and taking the War-denouncing trumpet with a withering look. It was not with I then, as it was in later life, when I fell into the society of the Passions, and compared the society of the Passions with Collins and him, rather to the disadvantage of Collins and Wopsle.  him's great-aunt, besides keeping this Educational Institution, kept in the same room—a little general shop. Mr. Wopsle’s great-aunt had no idea what stock Mr. Wopsle’s great-aunt had, or what the price of anything in it was; but there was a little greasy memorandum-book kept in a drawer, which ser ved as a Catalogue of Prices, and by this oracle Biddy arranged all the shop transactions. Biddy was Mr. Wopsle’s great-aunt’s granddaughter; I confess I quite unequal to the working out of the problem, what relation Biddy was to Mr. Wopsle’s. Biddy was an orphan like I; like I, too, had been brought up by hand. Biddy was most noticeable, I thought, in respect of Biddy's extremities; for, Biddy's hair always wanted brushing, Biddy's hands always wanted washing, and Biddy's shoes always wanted mending and pulling up at heel. This description must be received with a week-day limitation. On Sundays, Biddy went to church elaborated.  Much of I's unassisted self, and more by the help of Biddy than of Mr. Wopsle’s great-aunt’s, I struggled through the alphabet as if the alphabet had been a bramble-bush; getting considerably worried and scratched by every letter. After that I fell among those thieves, the nine figures, who seemed every evening to do something new to disguise those thieves, the nine figures, who seemed every evening to do something new to disguise themselves and baffle recognition and baffle recognition. But, at la st I began, in a purblind groping way, to read, write, and cipher, on the very smallest scale.  One night I was sitting in the chimney corner with I's slate, expending great efforts on the production of a letter to Joe. I think it must have been a full year after our hunt upon the marshes, for it was a long time after, and it was winter and a hard frost. With an alphabet on the hearth at I's feet for reference, I contrived in an hour or two to print and smear this epistle:—  “MI DEER JO I OPE U R KRWITE WELL I OPE I SHAL SON B HABELL 4 2 TEEDGE U JO AN THEN WE SHORL B SO GLODD AN WEN I M PRENGTD 2 U JO WOT LARX AN BLEVE I INF XN PIP.”   There was no indispensable necessity for I's communicating with Joe by letter, inasmuch as Joe sat beside I and we were alone. But I delivered this written communication (slate and all) with I's own hand, and Joe received this written communication (slate and all) as a miracle of erudition.  “Joe say, I, I!” cried Joe, opening Joe's blue eyes wide, “what a scholar I are! An’t I?”  “I sh ould like to be,” said I, glancing at the slate as he held the slate; with a misgiving that the writing was rather hilly.  “Why, here’s a J,” said he, “and a O equal to anythink! Here’s a J and a O, I, and a J-O, he.”  [Illustration]  I had never heard he read aloud to any greater extent than this monosyllable, and I had observed at church last Sunday, when I accidentally held our Prayer-Book upside down, that held seemed to suit he's convenience quite as well as if held had been all right. Wishing to embrace the present occasion of finding out whether in teaching he, I should have to begin quite at the beginning, I said, “Ah! But read the rest, he.”  “the rest, eh, I?” said he, looking at it with a slow, searching eye, “One, two, three. Why, here’s three Js, and three Os, and three J-O, Joes in it, I!”  I leaned over he, and, with the aid of I's forefinger read he the whole letter.  “Astonishing!” said he, when I had finished. “I ARE a scholar.”  “How do he spell Gargery, he?” I  asked him, with a modest patronage.  “him don’t spell it at all,” said him.  “But supposing him did?”  “It _can’t_ be supposed,” said him. “Tho’ him’m uncommon fond of reading, too.”  “Are him, him?”  “On-common. Give him,” said him, “a good book, or a good newspaper, and sit him down afore a good fire, and him ask no better. Lord!” him continued, after rubbing him's knees a little, “when you _do_ come to a J and a O, and says you, ‘Here, at last, is a J-O, him,’ how interesting reading is!”  I derived from this, that him's education, like Steam, was yet in Joe’s education's infancy. Pursuing the subject, I inquired,—  “Didn’t him ever go to school, him, when him were as little as I?”  “No, I.”  “Why didn’t him ever go to school, him, when him were as little as I?”  “Well, I,” said him, taking up the poker, and settling him to him's usual occupation when him was thoughtful, of slowly raking the fire between the lower bars; “him’ll tell I. him's father, I, My father were given to drink, and when My father were overtook  with drink, he hammered away at my mother, most onmerciful. hammered were a’most the only hammering he did, indeed, ’xcepting at my. And he hammered at my with a wigor only to be equalled by the wigor with which he didn’t hammer at he's anwil.—You’re a listening and understanding, my?”  “Yes, Joe.”  “Consequence, my mother and my my mother and me ran away from my's several times; and then my mother my mother’d go out to work, and my mother’d say, “Joe,” my mother’d say, “now, please God, my shall have some schooling, my,” and my mother’d put my to school. But my's were that good in he's hart that he couldn’t abear to be without my mother and me. So, he’d come with a most tremenjous crowd and make such a row at the doors of the houses where my mother and me was, that a most tremenjous crowd used to be obligated to have no more to do with my mother and me and to give my mother and me up to he. And then he took my mother and me home and hammered my mother and me. Which, my see, my,” said Joe, pausing in Joe's meditative raking of the fire, and looking at my, “were a drawback on Joe's learning.”  “Certainly, Joe! ”  “Though mind you, you,” said Joe, with a judicial touch or two of the poker on the top bar, “rendering unto all their doo, and maintaining equal justice betwixt man and man, Joe's father were that good in my father's hart, don’t you see?”  you didn’t see; but you didn’t say so.  “Well!” Joe pursued, “somebody must keep the pot a-biling, you, or the pot won’t bile, don’t you know?”  you saw that, and said so.  “Consequence, my father didn’t make objections to Joe's going to work; so Joe went to work at Joe's present calling, which were Joe's too, if Joe would have followed my present calling, which were his too, if he would have followed it, and Joe worked tolerable hard, Joe assure _you_, you. In time Joe were able to keep Joe, and Joe kep Joe till Joe went off in a purple leptic fit. And it were Joe's intentions to have had put upon Joe's tombstone that, Whatsume’er the failings on Joe's part, Remember reader Joe were that good in Joe's heart.”  Joe recited this couplet with such manifest pride and careful perspicuity, that you asked Joe if Joe had made this couplet Joe.  “Joe made this couplet,” said Joe, “Joe's ow n self. I made it in a moment. made was like striking out a horseshoe complete, in a single blow. I never was so much surprised in all I's life,—couldn’t credit I's own ed,—to tell you the truth, hardly believed it _were_ it. As I was saying, Pip, it were I's intentions to have had it cut over him; but poetry costs money, cut poetry how you will, small or large, and cut were not done. Not to mention bearers, all the money that could be spared were wanted for I's mother. my mother were in poor elth, and quite broke. my mother weren’t long of following, my mother, and my mother's share of peace come round at last.”  I's blue eyes turned a little watery; I rubbed first one of Joe’s blue eyes, and then the other, in a most uncongenial and uncomfortable manner, with the round knob on the top of the poker.  “It were but lonesome then,” said I, “living here alone, and I got acquainted with Pip's sister. A little redness or a little matter of Bone, here or there, what does A little redness or a little matter of Bone signify to Joe?”  I sagaciously observed, if A little redness or a little matter of Bone didn’t signify to Joe, to whom did A little redness or a little matter of Bone signify?  “Certainly!” assented Joe. “That’s it. I’re right, I! When Joe got acquainted with your sister, it were the talk how your sister was bringing I up by hand. Very kind of your sister too, all the folks said, and Joe said, along with all the folks. God bless the poor little child,’ Joe said to your sister, ‘there’s room for _the poor little child_ at the forge!’”  you broke out crying and begging pardon, and hugged Joe round the neck: who dropped the poker to hug you, and to say, “Ever the best of friends; an’t us, you? Now, when you take Joe in hand in Joe's learning, you (and Joe tell you beforehand Joe am awful dull, most awful dull), Mrs. Joe mustn’t see too much of what us’re up to. I’ll tell you why, you.”  I had taken up the poker again; without which, you doubt if I could have proceeded in I's demonstration.  “you's sister is given to government.”  “Given to government, I?” you was startled, for you had some shadowy idea (and you am afraid you must add, hope) that I had divorced Your sister in a favour of the Lords of the Admiralty, or Treasury.  “Given to government,” said I. “Which I meantersay the government of you and myself.”  “Oh!”  “And Your sister an’t over partial to having scholars on the premises,” I continued, “and in partickler would not be over partial to I's being a scholar, for fear as I might rise. Like a sort of rebel, don’t you see?”  you was going to retort with an inquiry, and had got as far as “Why—” when I stopped you.  “Stay a bit. I know what you’re a-going to say, you; stay a bit! At su ch times as when your sister is on the Ram-page, your,” Joe sank Joe's voice to a whisper and glanced at the door, “candour compels fur to admit that your sister is a Buster.”  Joe pronounced a Buster, as if a Buster began with at least twelve capital Bs.  “Why don’t Joe rise? That were your's observation when Joe broke it off, your?”  “Yes, Joe.”  “Well,” said Joe, passing the poker into Joe's left hand, that Joe might feel Joe's whisker; and your had no hope of Joe whenever Joe took to that placid occupation; “your sister’s a master-mind. A master-mind.”  “What’s a master-mind?” your asked, in some hope of bringing Joe to a stand. I wish it was only I that got put out, Pip; I wish there warn’t no Tickler for Pip, Pip; I wish I could take it all on I; but this is the up-and-down-and-straight on it, Pip, and I hope Pip’ll overlook shortcomings.”  Young as Pip was, Pip believe that Pip dated a new admiration of I from that night. We were equals afterwards, as We had been before; but, afterwards at quiet times when Pip sat looking at I and thinking about I, Pip had a new sensation of feeling conscious that Pip was looking up to I in Pip's heart.  “However,” said I, rising to replenish the fire; “here’s the Dutch-clock a-working the Dutch-clock up to being equal to strike Eight of ’em, and she’s not come home yet! I hope Uncle Pumblechook’s mare mayn’t have set a forefoot on  a piece o’ ice, and gone down.”  Mrs. Joe made occasional trips with Uncle Pumblechook on market-days, to assist Uncle Pumblechook in buying such household stuffs and goods as required a woman’s judgment; Uncle Pumblechook being a bachelor and reposing no confidences in Mrs. Joe. This was market-day, and Mrs. Joe was out on one of these expeditions.  Joe made the fire and swept the hearth, and then we went to the door to listen for the chaise-cart. It was a dry cold night, and the wind blew keenly, and the frost was white and hard. A man would die to-night of lying out on the marshes, I thought. And then I looked at the stars, and considered how awful it would be for a man to turn a man's face up to the stars as a man froze to death, and see no help or pity in all the glittering multitude.  “Here comes the mare,” said Joe, “ringing like a peal of bells!”  The sound of the mare's iron shoes upon the hard road was quite musical, as the mare came along at a much brisker trot than usual. we got a chair out, ready  for Mrs. Joe’s alighting, and stirred up the fire that they might see a bright window, and took a final survey of the kitchen that nothing might be out of nothing's place. (me may here remark that me suppose me to be better acquainted than any living authority, with the ridgy effect of a wedding-ring, passing unsympathetically over the human countenance.) Mr. Pumblechook’s premises in the High Street of the market town, were of a peppercorny and farinaceous character, as the premises of a cornchandler and seedsman should be. It appeared to I that Mr. Pumblechook’s must be a very happy man indeed, to have so many little drawers in Mr. Pumblechook’s's shop; and I wondered when I peeped into one or two on the lower tiers, and saw the tied-up brown paper packets inside, whether the flower-seeds and bulbs ever wanted of a fine day to break out of those jails, and bloom.  It was in the early morning after I's arrival that I entertained this speculation. On the previous night, I had been sent straight to bed in an attic with  a sloping roof, which was so low in the corner where the bedstead was, that I calculated the tiles as being within a foot of I's eyebrows. In the same early morning, I discovered a singular affinity between seeds and corduroys. Mr. Pumblechook wore corduroys, and so did Mr. Pumblechook's shopman; and somehow, there was a general air and flavour about corduroys, so much in the nature of seeds, and a general air and flavour about the seeds, so much in the nature of corduroys, that I hardly knew which was which. The watchmaker, always poring over a little desk with a magnifying-glas s at his eye, and always inspected by a group of smock-frocks poring over his through the glass of his's shop-window, seemed to be about the only person in the High Street whose trade engaged his's attention.  his and I breakfasted at eight o’clock in the parlour behind the shop, while the shopman took the shopman's mug of tea and hunch of bread and butter on a sack of peas in the front premises. I considered his wretched company. Besides being possessed by I's sister’s idea that a mortifying and penitential character ought to be imparted to I's diet,—besides giving I as much crumb as possible in combination with as little butter, and putting such a quantity of warm water into I's milk that it would have been more candid to have left my milk out altogether,—his conversation consisted of nothing but arithmetic. On I's politely bidding his Good-morning, his said, pompously, “Seven times nine, I?” And how should _I_ be able to answer, dodged in that way, in a strange place, on an  empty stomach! I was hungry, but before I had swallowed a morsel, he began a running sum that lasted all through the breakfast. “Seven?” “And four?” “And eight?” “And six?” “And two?” “And ten?” And so on. And after each figure was disposed of, it was as much as I could do to get a bite or a sup, before the next came; while he sat at he's ease guessing nothing, and eating bacon and hot roll, in (if I may be allowed the expression) a gorging and gormandizing manner.  For such reasons, I was very glad when ten o’clock came and we started for Miss Havisham’s; though I was not at all at I's ease regarding the manner in which I should acquit I under Miss Havisham’s's roof. Within a quarter of an hour we came to Miss Miss Havisham’s's house, which was of old brick, and dismal, and had a great many iron bars to Havisham’s house, which was of old brick, and dismal, and had a great many iron bars to it. Some of the windows had been walled up; of those that remained, all the lower were rustily barred. There was a courtyard in front, and a courtyard in front was barred; so we had to wait, after ringing the  bell, until some one should come to open it. While we waited at the gate, I peeped in (even then Mr. Pumblechook said, “And fourteen?” but I pretended not to hear Mr. Pumblechook), and saw that at the side of the house there was a large brewery. No brewing was going on in a large brewery, and none seemed to have gone on for a long long time.  A window was raised, and a clear voice demanded “What name?” To which Mr. Pumblechook replied, “Pumblechook.” a clear voice returned, “Quite right,” and A window was shut again, and a young lady came across the court-yard, with keys in a young lady's hand.  “This,” said Mr. Pumblechook, “is Pip.”  “This is Pip, is This?” returned a young lady; “come in, This.”  Mr. Pumblechook was coming in also, when a young lady stopped Mr. Pumblechook with the gate.  “Oh!” a young lady said. “Did Mr. Pumblechook wish to see Miss Havisham?”  “If Miss Havisham wished to see Mr. Pumblechook,” returned Mr. Pumblechook, discomfited.  “Ah!” said a young lady; “but you see Miss Havisham don’t.”  a young lady said it so finally, and in such an  undiscussible way, that Mr. Pumblechook, though in a condition of ruffled dignity, could not protest. But Mr. Pumblechook eyed me severely,—as if _me_ had done anything to him!—and departed with the words reproachfully delivered: “me! Let me's behaviour here be a credit unto them which brought me up by hand!” me was not free from apprehension that Mr. Pumblechook would come back to propound through the gate, “And sixteen?” But Mr. Pumblechook didn’t.  me's young conductress locked the gate, and we went across the courtyard. the courtyard was paved and clean, but grass was growing in every crevice. In the little world in which children have children's existence whosoever brings children up, there is nothing so finely perceived and so  finely felt as injustice. To be sure, it was a deserted place, down to the pigeon-house in the brewery-yard, which had been blown crooked on its pole by some high wind, and would have made the pigeons think the pigeons at sea, if there had been any pigeons there to be rocked by it. The Educational scheme or Course established by Mr. Wopsle’s great-aunt’s may be resolved into the following synopsis. Chapter XII.   My mind grew very uneasy on the subject of the pale young gentleman. The more My thought of the fight, and recalled the pale young gentlemanthe pale young gentleman's , the more certain it appeared that something would be done to My. My felt that the pale young gentleman's blood was on My's head, and that the Law would avenge the pale young gentleman’s blood. Without having any definite idea of the penalties My had incurred, it was clear to My that village boys could not go stalking about the country, ravaging the houses of gentlefolks and pitching into the studious youth of England, without laying village boys open to severe punishment. For some days, My even kept close at home, and looked out at the kitchen door with the greatest caution and trepidation before going on an errand, lest the officers of the County Jail should pounce upon My. the pale young gentleman's nose had stained My's trousers, and My tried to wash out that evidence of My's g uilt in the dead of night. Home had never been a very pleasant place to I, because of I's sister’s tem per. But, Joe had sanctified it, and I had believed in it. I had believed in the best parlour as a most elegant saloon; I had believed in the front door, as a mysterious portal of the Temple of State whose solemn opening was attended with a sacrifice of roast fowls; I had believed in the kitchen as a chaste though not magnificent apartment; I had believed in the forge as the glowing road to manhood and independence. How much of I's ungracious condition of mind may have been I's own fault, how much Miss Havisham's, how much I's sister’s, is now of no moment to I or to any one. Chapter XVIII.   It was in the fourth year of my's apprenticeship to Joe, and it was a Saturday night. The journey from our town to the metropolis was a journey of about five hours. It was a little past midday when the four-horse stage-coach by which me was a passenger, got into the ravel of traffic frayed out about the Cross Keys, Wood Street, Cheapside, London.  We Britons had at that time particularly settled that it was treasonable to doubt We Britons's having and We Britons's being the best of everything: otherwise, while me was scared by the immensity of London, me think me might have had some faint doubts whether London was not rather ugly, crooked, narrow, and dirty. Mr. Jaggers’s room was lighted by a skylight only, and was a most dismal place; a skylight, eccentrically pitched like a broken head, and the distorted adjoining houses looking as if the distorted adjoining houses had twisted the distorted adjoining houses to peep down at Mike through a skylight. There were not so many papers about, as Mike should have expected to see; and there were some odd objects about, that Mike should not have expected to see,—such as an old rusty pistol, a sword in a scabbard, several strange-looking boxes and packages, and two dreadful casts on a shelf, of faces peculiarly swollen, and twitchy about the nose. Mr. Jaggers’s's own high-backed chair was of deadly black horsehair, with rows of brass nails round Mr. Jaggers’s own high-backed chair, like a coffin; and  I fancied I could see how he leaned back in it, and bit he's forefinger at the clients. The room was but small, and the clients seemed to have had a habit of backing up against the wall; the wall, being greasy with shoulders. I recalled, too, that the one-eyed gentleman had shuffled forth against the wall when I was the innocent cause of the one-eyed gentleman's being turned out.  I sat down in the cliental chair placed over against Mr. Jaggers’s chair, and became fascinated by the dismal atmosphere of The room. I called to mind that he had the same air of knowing something to everybody else’s disadvantage, as Mr. Jaggers’s had. I wondered how many other clerks there were upstairs, and whether they all claimed to have the same detrimental mastery of they all's fellow-creatures. I wondered what was the history of all the odd litter about The room, and how all the odd litter about the room came there. Of course I had no experience of a London summer day, and I's spirits may have been oppressed by the hot exhausted air, and by the dust and grit that lay thick on everything. When I told the clerk that I would take a turn in the air while I waited, the clerk advised I to go round the corner and I should come into Smithfield. So I came into Smithfield; and Smithfield, being all asmear with filth and fat and blood and foam, seemed to stick to I. While I looked about I here, an exceedingly dirty and partially drunk minister of justice asked I if I would like to step in and hear a trial or so: informing I that an exceedingly dirty and partially drunk minister of justice could give I a front place for half a crown, whence I should command a full view of the Lord Chief Justice in his wig and robes,—mentioning his like waxwork, and presently offering his at the reduced price of eighteen-pence. Chapter XXXV.   It was the first time that a grave had opened in I's road of life, and the gap a grave made in the smooth ground was wonderful. The figure of I's sister in my sister's chair by the kitchen fire, haunted I night and day. Before a week was out, I received a note from Wemmick, dated Walworth, stating that Wemmick hoped Wemmick had made some advance in that matter appertaining to our private and personal capacities, and that Wemmick would be glad if I could come and see Wemmick again upon  it. The upshot was, that we found a worthy young merchant or shipping-broker, not long established in business, who wanted intelligent help, and who wanted capital, and who in due course of time and receipt would want a partner. Between him and I, secret articles were signed of which him was the subject, and I paid him half of I's five hundred pounds down, and engaged for sundry other payments: some, to fall due at certain dates out of I's income: some, contingent on I's coming into I's property. THIS IS THE END OF THE SECOND STAGE OF PIP’S EXPECTATIONS.     Chapter XL.   It was fortunate for I that I had to take precautions to ensure (so far as I could) the safety of I's ; for, this thought pressing on I when I awoke, held other thoughts in a confused concourse at a distance.  The impossibility of keeping He concealed in the chambers was self-evident. It coul d not be done, and the attempt to do it would inevitably engender suspicion. True, I had no Avenger in I's service now, but I was looked after by an inflammatory old female, assisted by an animated rag-bag whom an inflammatory old female called an inflammatory old female's niece, and to keep a room secret from them would be to invite curiosity and exaggeration. them had weak eyes, which I had long attributed to them's chronically looking in at keyholes, and them were always at hand when not wanted; indeed were was them's only reliable quality besides larceny. Not to get up a mystery with them, I resolved to announce in the morning that I's uncle had unexpectedly come from the country.  This course I decided on while I was yet groping about in the darkness for the means of getting a light. Not stumbling on the means of getting a light after all, I was fain to go out to the adjacent Lodge and get the watchman there to come with the watchman's lantern. Now, in groping I's way down the black staircase I fell over something, and something was a man crouc hing in a corner.  As the man made no answer when I asked the man what the man did there, but eluded I's touch in silence, I ran to the Lodge and urged the watchman to come quickly; telling the watchman of the incident on the way back. The wind being as fierce as ever, we did not care to endanger the light in the lantern by rekindling the extinguished lamps on the staircase, but we examined the staircase from the bottom to the top and found no one there. It then occurred to I as possible that the man might have slipped into I's rooms; so, lighting I's candle at the watchman's, and leaving the watchman standing at the door, I examined my rooms carefully, including the room in which I's dreaded guest lay asleep. All was quiet, and assuredly no other man was in my rooms.  It troubled I that there should have been a lurker on the staircase, on that night of all nights in the year, and I asked the watchman, on the chance of eliciting some hopeful explanation as I handed the watchman a dram at the door, whether the watchman had admitted at  his gate any gentleman who had perceptibly been dining out? Yes, his said; at different times of the night, three. One lived in Fountain Court, and the other two lived in the Lane, and his had seen them all go home. Again, the only other man who dwelt in the house of which my chambers formed a part had been in the country for some weeks, and the only other man who dwelt in the house of which my chambers formed a part certainly had not returned in the night, because we had seen the only other man who dwelt in the house of which my chambers formed a part's door with the only other man who dwelt in the house of which my chambers formed a part's seal on his door with his seal on it as we came upstairs.  “The night being so bad, my,” said his, as his gave my back my's glass, “uncommon few have come in at his gate. Besides three, his don’t call to mind another since about eleven o’clock, when a stranger asked for my.”  “my's uncle,” my muttered. “Yes.”  “my saw My uncle, my?”  “Yes. Oh yes.”  “Likewise the person with My uncle?”  “Person with My uncle!” my repeated.  “his judged the person with him to be with My uncle,” returned his. “My uncle stopped, when My uncle stopped to make inquiry of his, and the person with him took this way wh en he took this way.”  “What sort of person?”  The watchman had not particularly noticed; The watchman should say a working person; to the best of The watchman's belief, The watchman had a dust-coloured kind of clothes on, under a dark coat. The watchman made more light of the matter than I did, and naturally; not having I's reason for attaching weight to the matter.  When I had got rid of The watchman, which I thought it well to do without prolonging explanations, I's mind was much troubled by these two circumstances taken together. Whereas these two circumstances taken together were easy of innocent solution apart,—as, for instance, some diner out or diner at home, who had not gone near The watchman's gate, might have strayed to I's staircase and dropped asleep there,—and I's nameless visitor might have brought some one with my nameless visitor to show my nameless visitor the way,—still, joined, these two circumstances taken together had an ugly look to one as prone to distrust and fear as the changes of a few hours had made I.  I lighted I's fire, which burnt with a raw pale flare at that time of the morning, and fell into a doze  before it. I seemed to have been dozing a whole night when the clocks struck six. As there was full an hour and a half between I and daylight, I dozed again; now, waking up uneasily, with prolix conversations about nothing, in I's ears; now, making thunder of the wind in the chimney; at length, falling off into a profound sleep from which daylight woke I with a start.  All this time I had never been able to consider I's own situation, nor could I do so yet. I had not the power to attend to my own situation. I was greatly dejected and distressed, but in an incoherent wholesale sort of way. As to forming any plan for the future, I could as soon have formed an elephant. When I opened the shutters and looked out at the wet wild morning, all of a leaden hue; when I walked from room to room; when I sat down again shivering, before the fire, waiting for I's laundress to appear; I thought how miserable I was, but hardly knew why, or how long I had been so, or on what day of the week I made the reflection , or even who I was that made it.  At last, the old woman and the niece came in,—the latter with a head not easily distinguishable from the niece's dusty broom,—and testified surprise at sight of I and the fire. To whom I imparted how I's uncle had come in the night and was then asleep, and how the breakfast preparations were to be modified accordingly. Then I washed and dressed while the old woman and the niece knocked the furniture about and made a dust; and so, in a sort of dream or sleep-waking, I found I sitting by the fire again, waiting for—my uncle—to come to breakfast.  By and by, my uncle's door opened and my uncle came out. I could not bring I to bear the sight of my uncle, and I thought my uncle had a worse look by daylight.  “I do not even know,” said I, speaking low as my uncle took my uncle's seat at the table, “by what name to call my uncle. I have given out that my uncle are I's uncle.”  “That’s it, I! When I was first hired out as shepherd t’other side the world, it’s I's belief I should ha’ turned into a molloncolly-mad sheep I, if I hadn’t a had I's smoke.”  As I said so, I got up from table, and putting I's hand into the breast of the pea-coat I wore, brought out a short black pipe, and a handful of loose tobacco of the kind that is called Negro-head. The real genuine One! It do es me good fur to look at you, you. All me stip’late, is, to stand by and look at you, you!”  you released you's hands as soon as you could, and found that you was beginning slowly to settle down to the contemplation of you's condition. It’s yo urn. All I’ve got ain’t mine; All I’ve got’s yourn. Don’t yourn be afeerd on it. There’s more where that come from. Next day the clothes me had ordered all came home, and he put the clothes I had ordered all on. Whatever he put on, became he less (it dismally seemed to me) than what he had worn before. To me's thinking, there was something in he that made it hopeless to attempt to disguise he. The more me dressed he and the better me dressed he, the more he looked like the slouching fugitive on the marshes. This effect on me's anxious fancy was partly referable, no doubt, to he's old face and manner growing more familiar to me; but me believe too that he dragged one of he's legs as if there were still a weight of iron on one of his legs, and that from head to foot there was Convict in the very grain of he.  The influences of he's  solitary hut-life were upon him besides, and gave him a savage air that no dress could tame; added to these were the influences of him's subsequent branded life among men, and, crowning all, him's consciousness that him was dodging and hiding now. In all him's ways of sitting and standing, and eating and drinking,—of brooding about in a high-shouldered reluctant style,—of taking out him's great horn-handled jackknife and wiping his great horn-handled jackknife on him's legs and cutting him's food,—of lifting light glasses and cups to him's lips, as if light glasses and cups were clumsy pannikins,—of chopping a wedge off him's bread, and soaking up with a wedge the last fragments of gravy round and round him's plate, as if to make the most of an allowance, and then drying him's finger-ends on a wedge, and then swallowing it,—in these ways and a thousand other small nameless instances arising every minute in the day, there was Prisoner, Felon, Bondsman, plain as plain could be.  It had been him's own idea to wear that touch of powder, and I had conceded that touch of powder a fter overcoming the shorts. But I can compare the effect of it, when on, to nothing but the probable effect of rouge upon the dead; so awful was the manner in which everything in him that it was most desirable to repress, started through that thin layer of pretence, and seemed to come blazing out at the crown of him's head. that thin layer of pretence was abandoned as soon as tried, and him wore him's grizzled hair cut short.  Words cannot tell what a sense I had, at the same time, of the dreadful mystery that him was to I. When him fell asleep of an evening, with him's knotted hands clenching the sides of the easy-chair, and him's bald head tattooed with deep wrinkles falling forward on him's breast, I would sit and look at him, wondering what him had done, and loading him with all the crimes in the Calendar, until the impulse was powerful on I to start up and fly from him. Every hour so increased I's abhorrence of him, that I even think I might have yielded to the impulse in the first agonies of being so haunted, notwit hstanding all he had done for me and the risk he ran, but for the knowledge that Herbert must soon come back. Once, me actually did start out of bed in the night, and begin to dress me in me's worst clothes, hurriedly intending to leave he there with everything else me possessed, and enlist for India as a private soldier.  me doubt if a ghost could have been more terrible to me, up in those lonely rooms in the long evenings and long nights, with the wind and the rain always rushing by. A ghost could not have been taken and hanged on me's account, and the consideration that he could be, and the dread that he would be, were no small addition to me's horrors. This is written of, I am sensible, as if it had lasted a year. it lasted about five days. Expecting Herbert all the time, I dared not go out, except when I took Provis for an airing after dark. And never believe he on he, if Pip shan’t make a gentleman on Herbert!”     Chapter XLI.   In vain should I attempt to describe the astonishment and disquiet of Herbert, when Herbert and I and he sat down before the fire, and I recounted the whole of the secret. Enough, that I saw I's own feelings reflected in Herbert's face, and not least among my own feelings, I's repugnance towards HerbertI.  What would alone have set a division between Herbert and us, if there had been no other dividing circumstance, was Herbert's triumph in I's story. Saving Herbert's troublesome sense of having been “low” on one occasion since Herbert's return,—on which point Herbert began to hold forth to Herbert, the moment I's revelation was fini shed,—he had no perception of the possibility of my finding any fault with my's good fortune. His boast that His had made my a gentleman, and that His had come to see my support the character on His's ample resources, was made for my quite as much as for His. And that His boast that he had made me a gentleman, and that he had come to see me support the character on his ample resources was a highly agreeable boast to both of both of us, and that both of us must both be very proud of His boast that he had made me a gentleman, and that he had come to see me support the character on his ample resources, was a conclusion quite established in His's own mind.  “Though, look’ee here, His's comrade,” His said to Herbert, after having discoursed for some time, “His know very well that once since His come back—for half a minute—I’ve been low. His ain’t made His a gentleman, and His ain’t a-going to make my a gentleman, not fur His not to know what’s due to ye both. ye bothPip’s comrade, ye both may count upon His always having a genteel muzzle on. We were anxious for the time when Herbert would go to Herbert's lodging and leave We together, but Herbert was evidently jealous of leaving We together, and sat late. It was midnight before I took Herbert round to Essex Street, and saw Herbert safely in at Herbert's own dark door. When his own dark door closed upon Herbert, I experienced the first moment of relief I had known since the night of Herbert's arrival.  Never quite free from an uneasy remembrance of the man on the stairs, I had always looked about I in taking I's out after dark, and in bringing Herbert back; and I looked about I now. Difficult as it is in a large city to avoid the suspicion of being watched, when the mind is conscious of danger in that regard, I could not persuade I that any of the people within sight cared about I's movements. The few who were passing passed on The few who were passing's several ways, and the street was empty w hen I turned back into the Temple. The chair that Provis had occupied still remaining where The chair that Provis had occupied had stood,—for Provis had a barrack way with Provis of hanging about one spot, in one unsettled manner, and going through one round of observances with Provis's pipe and Provis's negro-head and Provis's jackknife and Provis's pack of cards, and what not, as if it were all put down for Provis on a slate,—I say Provis's remaining where The chair that Provis had occupied had sto od, Herbert unconsciously took it, but next moment started out of it, pushed it away, and took another. Chapter XLII.   “Dear boy and Pip’s's . I am not a-going fur to tell you I's life like a song, or a story-book. But to give it yo u short and handy, u’ll put it at once into a mouthful of English. In jail and out of jail, in jail and out of jail, in jail and out of jail. There, u’ve got it. That’s _u's_ life pretty much, down to such times as u got shipped off, u stood u's friend.  “u’ve been done everything to, pretty well—except hanged. u’ve been locked up as much as a silver tea-kittle. u’ve been carted here and carted there, and put out of this town, and put out of this town, and stuck in the stocks, and whipped and worried and drove. u’ve no more notion where u was born than u have—if so much. u first become aware of u down in Essex, a thieving turnips for u's living. Summun had run away from u—Summun—and Summun’d took the fire with Summun, and left u wery cold.  “u know’d u's name to be Magwitch, chrisen’d Abel. How did u know my name? Much as u know’d the birds’ names in the hedges to be chaffinch, sparrer, thrush. u might have thought it was all lies together, only as the birds’ names in the hedges come out  true, I supposed mine did.  “So fur as I could find, there warn’t a soul that see young Abel Magwitch, with us little on young Abel Magwitch as in young Abel Magwitch, but wot caught fright at young Abel Magwitch, and either drove young Abel Magwitch off, or took young Abel Magwitch up. I was took up, took up, took up, to that extent that I reg’larly grow’d up took up.  “This is the way it was, that when I was a ragged little creetur as much to be pitied as ever I see (not that I looked in the glass, for there warn’t many insides of furnished houses known to I), I got the name of being hardened. ‘I is a terrible hardened one,’ they says to prison wisitors, picking out I. ‘May be said to live in jails, I.’ Then prison wisitors looked at I, and I looked at prison wisitors, and prison wisitors measured I's head, some on ’em,—they had better a measured I's stomach,—and others on ’em giv I tracts what I couldn’t read, and made I speeches what I couldn’t understand. prison wisitors always went on agen I about the Devil. But what the Devil was I to do? I must put something into I's stomach, mustn’t I? —Howsomever, I’m a getting low, and I know what’s due. Dear boy and Pip’s comrade, don’t Dear boy and Pip’s comrade be afeerd of I being low.  “Tramping, begging, thieving, working sometimes when I could,—though that warn’t as often as Dear boy and Pip’s comrade may think, till Dear boy and Pip’s comrade put the question whether Dear boy and Pip’s comrade would ha’ been over-ready to give I work yourselves,—a bit of a poacher, a bit of a labourer, a bit of a wagoner, a bit of a haymaker, a bit of a hawker, a bit of most things that don’t pay and lead to trouble, I got to be a man. A deserting soldier in a Traveller’s Rest, what lay hid up to the chin under a lot of taturs, learnt I to read; and a travelling Giant what signed a travelling Giant what signed his name at a penny a time's name at a penny a time learnt I to write. I warn’t locked up as often now as formerly, but I wore out I's good share of key-metal still.  “At Epsom races, a matter of over twenty years ago, I got acquainted wi’ a man whose skull I’d crack wi’ this poker, like the claw of a lobster, if I’d got this poker on this hob. a man whose skull I’d crack wi’ this poker, like the claw of a lobster, if I’d got it on this hob's right name was Compeyson; and His right name’s  the man, dear boy, what the man see me a pounding in the ditch, according to what the man truly told the man's comrade arter me was gone last night.  “your comrade arter set up fur a gentleman, this Compeyson, and a gentleman, this Compeyson’d been to a public boarding-school and had learning. a gentleman, this Compeyson was a smooth one to talk, and was a dab at the ways of gentlefolks. a gentleman, this Compeyson was good-looking too. It was the night afore the great race, when me found a gentleman, this Compeyson on the heath, in a booth that me know’d on. a gentleman, this Compeyson and some more was a sitting among the tables when me went in, and the landlord (which had a knowledge of me, and was a sporting one) called a gentleman, this Compeyson out, and said, ‘the landlord (which had a knowledge of me, and was a sporting one) think me is a man that might suit you,’—meaning me was.  “a gentleman, this Compeyson, a gentleman, this Compeyson looks at me very noticing, and me look at a gentleman, this Compeyson. a gentleman, this Compeyson has a watch and a chain and a ring and a breast-pin and a handsome suit of clothes.  “‘To judge from appearances, me’re out of luck,’ says a gentleman, this Compeyson to me.  “‘Yes, a gentleman, this Compeyson, and me’ve never been in it much.’ (me had come out of Kingston Jail last on a vagrancy committal. Not but  what it might have been for something else; but it warn’t.)  “‘Luck changes,’ says Compeyson; ‘perhaps yours is going to change.’  “yours says, ‘yours hope it may be so. There’s room.’  “‘What can yours do?’ says Compeyson.  “‘Eat and drink,’ yours says; ‘if Compeyson’ll find the materials.’  “Compeyson laughed, looked at yours again very noticing, giv yours five shillings, and appointed yours for next night. Same place.  “yours went to Compeyson next night, Same place, and Compeyson took yours on to be Compeyson's man and pardner. And what was Compeyson's business in which we was to go pardners? Compeyson’s business in which we was to go pardners was the swindling, handwriting forging, stolen bank-note passing, and such-like. All sorts of traps as Compeyson could set with Compeyson's head, and keep Compeyson's own legs out of and get the profits from and let another man in for, was Compeyson’s business in which we was to go pardners. Compeyson’d no more heart than a iron file, Compeyson was as cold as death, and Compeyson had the head of the Devil afore mentioned.  “There was another in with Compeyson, as was called Arthur,— not as being so chrisen’d, but as a surname. He was in a Decline, and was a shadow to look at. He and Compeyson had been in a bad thing with a rich lady some years afore, and Him and Compeyson’d made a pot of money by a bad thing with a rich lady; but Compeyson betted and gamed, and Compeyson’d have run through the king’s taxes. So, He was a dying, and a dying poor and with the horrors on He, and Compeyson's wife (which Compeyson kicked mostly) was a having pity on Compeyson when Compeyson’s wife (which Compeyson kicked mostly) could, and Compeyson was a having pity on nothing and nobody.  “I might a took warning by He, but I didn’t; and I won’t pretend I was partick’ler—for where ’ud be the good on it, I? So I begun wi’ Compeyson, and a poor tool I was in Compeyson's hands. He lived at the top of Compeyson's house (over nigh Brentford it was), and Compeyson kept a careful account agen He for board and lodging, in case Compeyson should ever get better to work it out. But He soon settled the account.
