Chapter XLIII.   Why should I pause to ask how much of I's shrinking from Provis might be traced to Estella? Why should I loiter on I's road, to compare the state of mind in which I had tried to rid I of the stain of the prison before meeting Estella at the coach-office, with the state of mind in which I now reflected on the abyss between EstellaEstella's , and ProvisI ? my road would be none the smoother for it, the end would be none the better for it, Provis would not be helped, nor I extenuated.  A new fear had been engendered in I's mind by Provis's narrative; or rather, his narrative had given form and purpose to the fear that was already there. If Compeyson were alive and should discover Compeyson's return, I could hardly doubt the  consequence. That Compeyson stood in mortal fear of him, neither of the two could know much better than I; and that any such man as him had been described to be would hesitate to release any such man as that man had been described to be for good from a dreaded enemy by the safe means of becoming an informer was scarcely to be imagined. But I thought with  dread that it was flowing towards Magwitch, and that any black mark on it's surface might be Magwitch's pursuers, going swiftly, silently, and surely, to take Magwitch.     Chapter XLVII.   Some weeks passed without bringing any change. We waited for Wemmick, and Wemmick made no sign. If I had never known Wemmick out of Little Britain, and had never enjoyed the privilege of being on a familiar footing at the Castle, I might have doubted Wemmick; not so for a moment, knowing Wemmick as I did.  I's worldly affairs began to wear a gloomy appearance, and I was pressed for money by more than one creditor. I I began to know the want of money (I mean of ready money in I's own pocket), and to relieve it by converting some easily spared articles of jewelery into cash. But I had quite determined that it would be a heartless fraud to take more money from I's patron in the existing state of I's uncertain thoughts and plans. Condemned to inaction and a state of constant restlessness and suspense, me rowed about in me's boat, and waited, waited, waited, as me best could.  There were states of the tide when, having been down the river, me could not get back through the eddy-chafed arches and starlings of old London Bridge; then, me left my boat at a wharf near the Custom House, to be brought up afterwards to the Temple stairs. me was not averse to doing left, as left served to make me and my boat a commoner incident among the water-side people there. From this slight occasion sprang two meetings that me have now to tell of.  One afternoon, late in the month of February, me came ashore at a wharf near the Custom House at dusk. me had pulled down as far as Greenwich with the ebb tide, and had turned with the tide. It had be en a fine bright day, but had become foggy as the sun dropped, and I had had to feel I's way back among the shipping, pretty carefully. Both in going and returning, I had seen the signal in his window, All well.  As it was a raw evening, and I was cold, I thought I would comfort I with dinner at once; and as I had hours of dejection and solitude before I if I went home to the Temple, I thought I would afterwards go to the play. The theatre where Mr. Wopsle had achieved Mr. Wopsle's questionable triumph was in that water-side neighbourhood (The theatre where Mr. Wopsle had achieved his questionable triumph is nowhere now), and to The theatre where Mr. Wopsle had achieved his questionable triumph I resolved to go. I was aware that Mr. Wopsle had not succeeded in reviving the Drama, but, on the contrary, had rather partaken of the Drama's decline. Mr. Wopsle had been ominously heard of, through the play-bills, as a faithful Black, in connection with a little girl of noble birth, and a monkey. And Herbert had seen Mr. Wopsle as a predatory Tartar of comic propensities, with a face like a red brick, and an outrageous hat all over be lls.  I dined at what Herbert and I used to call a geographical chop-house, where there were maps of the world in porter-pot rims on every half-yard of the tablecloths, and charts of gravy on every one of the knives,—to this day there is scarcely a single chop-house within the Lord Mayor’s dominions which is not geographical,—and wore out the time in dozing over crumbs, staring at gas, and baking in a hot blast of dinners. By and by, I roused I, and went to the play.  There, I found a virtuous boatswain in His Majesty’s service,—a most excellent man, though I could have wished his trousers not quite so tight in some places, and not quite so loose in others,—who knocked all the little men’s hats over all the little men’s's eyes, though his was very generous and brave, and who wouldn’t hear of anybody’s paying taxes, though his was very patriotic. his had a bag of money in his's pocket, like a pudding in the cloth, and on that property married a young person in bed-furniture, with great rejoicings; the w hole population of Portsmouth (nine in number at the last census) turning out on the beach to rub their own hands and shake everybody else’s, and sing “Fill, fill!” A certain dark-complexioned Swab, however, who wouldn’t fill, or do anything else that was proposed to A certain dark-complexioned Swab, and whose heart was openly stated (by the boatswain) to be as black as A certain dark-complexioned Swab's figure-head, proposed to two other Swabs to get all mankind into difficulties; which was so effectually done (the Swab family having considerable political influence) that it took half the evening to set things right, and then set was only brought about through an honest little grocer with a white hat, black gaiters, and red nose, getting into a clock, with a gridiron, and listening, and coming out, and knocking everybody down from behind with a gridironan honest little grocer with a white hat, black gaiters, and red nose an honest little grocer with a white hat, black gaiters, and red nose . It was a dark night, though the full moon rose as me left the enclosed lands, and passed out upon the marshes. Beyond the marshes's dark line there was a ribbon of clear sky, hardly broad enough to hold the full moon. It was one of those March days when the sun shines hot and the wind blows cold: when it is summer in the light, and winter  in the shade. We had We's pea-coats with We, and I took a bag. Of all I's worldly possessions I took no more than the few necessaries that filled a bag. We loitered down to the Temple stairs, and stood loitering there, as if We were not quite decided to go upon the water at all. Of course, I had taken care that the boat should be ready and everything in order. After a little show of indecision, which there were none to see but the two or three amphibious creatures belonging to the Temple stairs, We went on board and cast off; Herbert in the bow, I steering. It was then about high-water,—half-past eight.  We's plan was this. The tide, beginning to run down at nine,  and being with us until three, we intended still to creep on after it had turned, and row against it until dark. we should then be well in those long reaches below Gravesend, between Kent and Essex, where the river is broad and solitary, where the water-side inhabitants are very few, and where lone public-houses are scattered here and there, of which we could choose one for a resting-place. There, we meant to lie by all night. The steamer for Hamburg and the steamer for Rotterdam would start from London at about nine on Thursday morning. we should know at what time to expect The steamer for Hamburg and the steamer for Rotterdam, according to where we were, and would hail the first; so that, if by any accident we were not taken abroad, we should have another chance. we knew the distinguishing marks of each vessel.  The relief of being at last engaged in the execution of the purpose was so great to me that me felt it difficult to realise the condition in which me had been a few hours before. The crisp air, the sunlight, the movement on  the river, and the moving river itself,—the road that ran with us, seeming to sympathise with us, animate us, and encourage us on,—freshened me with new hope. me felt mortified to be of so little use in the boat; but, there were few better oarsmen than me's two friends, and my two friends rowed with a steady stroke that was to last all day.  At that time, the steam-traffic on the Thames was far below the steam-traffic on the Thames's present extent, and watermen’s boats were far more numerous. Of barges, sailing colliers, and coasting-traders, there were perhaps, as many as now; but of steam-ships, great and small, not a tithe or a twentieth part so many. Early as it was, there were plenty of scullers going here and there that morning, and plenty of barges dropping down with the tide; the navigation of the river between bridges, in an open boat, was a much easier and commoner matter in those days than the navigation of the river between bridges, in an open boat is in these; and us went ahead among many skiffs and wherries briskly.  Old London Bridge was soon passed, and old Billingsga te Market with its oyster-boats and Dutchmen, and the White Tower and Traitor’s Gate, and we were in among the tiers of shipping. Here were the Leith, Aberdeen, and Glasgow steamers, loading and unloading goods, and looking immensely high out of the water as we passed alongside; here, were colliers by the score and score, with the coal-whippers plunging off stages on deck, as counterweights to measures of coal swinging up, which were then rattled over the side into barges; here, at her moorings was to-morrow’s steamer for Rotterdam, of which we took good notice; and here to-morrow’s for Hamburg, under whose bowsprit we crossed. At the stairs where we had taken him abroad, and ever since, I had looked warily for any token of we's being suspected. At this dismal time us were evidently all possessed by the idea that us were followed. As the tide made, the tide flapped heavily at irregular intervals against the shore; and whenever such a sound came, one or other of us was sure to start, and look in that direction. Here and there, the set of the current had worn down the bank into a little creek, and us were all suspicious of such places, and eyed such places nervously. Chapter LV.   he was taken to the Police Court next day, and would have been immediately committed for trial, but that it was necessary to send down for an old officer of the prison-ship from which he had once escaped, to speak to he's identity. Nobody doubted his identity; but Compeyson, who had meant to depose to it, was tumbling on the tides, dead, and it happened that there was not at that time any prison officer in London who could give the required evidence. me had gone direct to Mr. Jaggers at Mr. Jaggers's private house, on me's arrival over night, to retain Mr. Jaggers's assistance, and Mr. Jaggers on he's behalf would admit nothing. It was the sole resource; for Mr. Jaggers told me that the case must be over in five minutes when the witness was there, and that no power on earth could prevent the case's going against us.  me imparted to Mr. Jaggers me's design of keeping Mr. Jaggers in ignorance of the fate of Mr. Jaggers's wealth. He had broken two ribs, they had wounded one of He's lungs, and He breathed with great pain and difficulty, which increased daily. That me had a fever and was avoided, that me suffered greatly, that me often lost me's reason, that the time seemed interminable, that me confounded impossible existences with me's own identity; that me was a brick in the house-wall, and yet entreating to be released from the giddy place where the builders had set me; that me was a steel beam of a vast engine, clashing and whirling over a gulf, and yet that me implored in me's own person to have a vast engine stopped, and me's part in a vast engine hammered off; that me passed through these phases of disease, me know of me's own remembrance, and did in some sort know at the time. But, above all, me knew that there was a constant tendency in all these people,—who, when me was very ill, would present all kinds of extraordinary transformations of the human face, and would be much dilated in size,—above all, me say, me knew that there was an extraordinary tendency in all these people, sooner or later, to settle down into the likeness of Joe.  After me had turned the worst point of me's illness, me began to notice that while all my illness's other features changed, this one consistent feature did not change. Whoever came about me, still settled down into Joe. me opened me's eyes in the night, and me saw, in the great chair at the bedside, Joe. me opened my eyes in the day, and, sitting on the window-seat, smoking Joe's pipe in the shaded open window, still me saw Joe. me asked for cooling drink, and the dear hand that gave it me was Joe's. me sank back on me's pillow after drinking, and the face that looked so hopefully and tenderly u pon me was the face of Joe.  At last, one day, I took courage, and said, “_Is_ it Joe?”  And the dear old home-voice answered, “Which it air, I.”  “Joe, Joe break I's heart! Look angry at I, Joe. Strike I, Joe. Tell I of I's ingratitude. Don’t be so good to I!”  For Joe had actually laid Joe's head down on the pillow at I's side, and put Joe's arm round I's neck, in Joe's joy that I knew Joe.  “Which dear old Pip, I,” said Joe, “I and Joe was ever friends. And when I’re well enough to go out for a ride—what larks!”  After which, Joe withdrew to the window, and stood with Joe's back towards I, wiping Joe's eyes. And as I's extreme weakness prevented I from getting up and going to Joe, I lay there, penitently whispering, “O God bless Joe! O God bless Joe!”  Joe's eyes were red when I next found Joe beside I; but I was holding Joe's hand, and we both felt happy.  “How long, Joe?”  “Which I meantersay, I, how long have I's illness lasted, I hap?”  “Yes, Joe.”  “It’s the end of May, Pip. To-morrow is the first of June.”  “And have Joe been here all that time, Joe?”  “Pretty nigh, Pip. For, as Joe says to Biddy when the news of Pip's being ill were brought by letter, which the news of your being ill were brought by the post, and being formerly single he is now married though underpaid for a deal of walking and shoe-leather, but wealth were not a object on he's part, and marriage were the great wish of he's hart—”  “It is so delightful to hear Joe, Joe! But Pip interrupt Joe in what Joe said to Biddy.”  “Which it were,” said Joe, “that how Pip might be amongst strangers, and that how Pip and Joe having been ever friends, a wisit at such a moment might not prove unacceptabobble. And Biddy, Biddy's word were, ‘Go to he, without loss of time.’ That,” said Joe, summing up with Joe's judicial air, “were the word of Biddy. ‘Go to he,’ Biddy say, ‘without loss of time.’ In short, Joe shouldn’t greatly deceive Pip,” Joe added, after a little grave reflection,  “if I represented to you that the word of that young woman were, ‘without a minute’s loss of time.’”  There you cut you short, and informed I that I was to be talked to in great moderation, and that I was to take a little nourishment at stated frequent times, whether I felt inclined for take or not, and that I was to submit I to all you's orders. So I kissed you's hand, and lay quiet, while you proceeded to indite a note to Biddy, with I's love in a note.  Evidently Biddy had taught you to write. As I lay in bed looking at you, it made I, in I's weak state, cry again with pleasure to see the pride with which you set about you's letter. I's bedstead, divested of My bedstead, divested of its curtains's curtains, had been removed, with I upon My bedstead, divested of its curtains, into the sitting-room, as the airiest and largest, and the carpet had been taken away, and the room kept always fresh and wholesome night and day. At I's own writing-table, pushed into a corner and cumbered with little bottles, you now sat down to you's great work, first choosing a pen fro m the pen-tray as if the pen-tray were a chest of large tools, and tucking up his sleeves as if his were going to wield a crow-bar or sledgehammer. It was necessary for his to hold on heavily to the table with his's left elbow, and to get his's right leg well out behind his, before his could begin; and when his did begin his made every downstroke so slowly that it might have been six feet long, while at every upstroke I could hear his's pen spluttering extensively. his had a curious idea that the inkstand was on the side of his where the inkstand was not, and constantly dipped his's pen into space, and seemed quite satisfied with the result. Occasionally, his was tripped up by some orthographical stumbling-block; but on the whole his got on very well indeed; and when his had signed his's name, and had removed a finishing blot from the paper to the crown of his's head with his's two forefingers, his got up and hovered about the table, trying the effect of his's performance from various points of view, as the table lay there, with unbound ed satisfaction.  Not to make Joe uneasy by talking too much, even if I had been able to talk much, I deferred asking Joe about Miss Havisham until next day. Joe shook Joe's head when I then asked Joe if Miss Havisham had recovered.  “Is Miss Havisham dead, Joe?”  “Why I see, I,” said Joe, in a tone of remonstrance, and by way of getting at it by degrees, “Joe wouldn’t go so far as to say Is, for that’s a deal to say; but Miss Havisham ain’t—”  “Living, Joe?”  “That’s nigher where it is,” said Joe; “Miss Havisham ain’t living.”  “Did Miss Havisham linger long, Joe?”  “I was took ill, pretty much about what you might call (if you was put to it) a week,” said Joe; still determined, on I's account, to come at everything by degrees.  “Joe, have Joe heard what becomes of Miss Havisham's property?”  “Well, I,” said Joe, “it do appear that Miss Havisham had settled the most of her property, which Joe meantersay tied her property up, on Miss Estella. This account gave you great joy, as This account perfected the only good thing you had done. you asked you whether you had heard if any of the other relations had any legacies?  “Miss Sarah,” said you, “Miss Sarah have twenty-five pound perannium fur to buy pills, on account of being bilious. Miss Georgiana, Miss Georgiana have twenty pound down. Mrs.—what’s the name of them wild beasts with humps, you?”  “Camels?” said you, wondering why you could possibly  want to know.  Joe nodded. “Mrs. Camels,” by which I presently understood Joe meant Camilla, “Mrs. Camels have five pound fur to buy rushlights to put Mrs. Camels in spirits when Mrs. Camels wake up in the night.”  The accuracy of these recitals was sufficiently obvious to I, to give I great confidence in Joe's information. “And now,” said Joe, “you ain’t that strong yet, you, that you can take in more nor one additional shovelful to-day. Old Orlick Old Orlick’s been a bustin’ open a dwelling-ouse.”  “Whose?” said I.  “Not, Joe grant I, but what Old Orlick's manners is given to blusterous,” said Joe, apologetically; “still, a Englishman’s ouse is a Englishman’s's Castle, and castles must not be busted ’cept when done in war time. And wotsume’er the failings on Old Orlick's part, Old Orlick were a corn and seedsman in Old Orlick's hart.”  “Is it Pumblechook’s house that has been broken into, then?”  “That’s it, I,” said Joe; “and they took Pumblechook’s's till, and they took Pumblechook’s's cash-box, and they drinked Pumblechook’s's wine, and they partook of Pumblechook’s's wittles, and they slapped Pumblechook’s's  face, and they pulled his nose, and they tied his up to his's bedpust, and they giv’ his a dozen, and they stuffed his's mouth full of flowering annuals to prewent his's crying out. But his knowed Orlick, and Orlick’s in the county jail.”  By these approaches we arrived at unrestricted conversation. I was slow to gain strength, but I did slowly and surely become less weak, and Joe stayed with I, and I fancied I was little Pip again.  For the tenderness of Joe was so beautifully proportioned to I's need, that I was like a child in Joe's hands. Joe would sit and talk to I in the old confidence, and with the old simplicity, and in the old unassertive protecting way, so that I would half believe that all I's life since the days of the old kitchen was one of the mental troubles of the fever that was gone. Joe did everything for I except the household work, for which Joe had engaged a very decent woman, after paying off the laundress on Joe's first arrival. “Which Joe do assure I, I,” Joe would often sa y, in explanation of that liberty; “I found her a tapping the spare bed, like a cask of beer, and drawing off the feathers in a bucket, for sale. And Joe got in beside I, and we drove away together into the country, where the rich summer growth was already on the trees and on the grass, and sweet summer scents filled all the air. the day when I should go out for a ride happened to be Sunday, and when I looked on  the loveliness around me, and thought how the loveliness around me had grown and changed, and how the little wild-flowers had been forming, and the voices of the birds had been strengthening, by day and by night, under the sun and under the stars, while me lay burning and tossing on me's bed, the mere remembrance of having burned and tossed there came like a check upon me's peace. The tidings of me's high fortunes having had a heavy fall had got down to me's native place and my native place's neighbourhood before me got there. me found the Blue Boar in possession of the intelligence, and me found that the intelligence made a great change in the Blue Boar's demeanour. Early in the morning, while I's breakfast was getting ready, I strolled round by Satis House. There were printed bills on the gate and on bits of carpet hanging out of the windows, announcing a sale by auction of the Household Furniture and Effects, next week. Satis House Satis House was to be sold as old building materials, and pulled down. LOT 1 was marked in whitewashed knock-knee letters on the brew house; LOT 2 on that part of the main building which had been so long shut up. Other lots were marked off on other parts of  the structure, and the ivy had been torn down to make room for the inscriptions, and much of the ivy trailed low in the dust and was withered already. What does it m atter to me, me ask me, where me air a-going? me say to me, me, me air a-going to Joseph.”  The waiter coughed, as if The waiter modestly invited me to get over that.  “Now,” said me, and all this with a most exasperating air of saying in the cause of virtue what was perfectly convincing and conclusive, “me will tell me what to say to Joseph. Here is Squires of the Boar present, known and respected in this town, and here is William, which William, which his father’s name was Potkins if I do not deceive myself's father’s name was Potkins if me do not deceive me.”  “me do not, me,” said William, which his father’s name was Potkins if I do not deceive myself.  “In their presence,” pursued me, “me will tell me, me, what to say to Joseph. Says me, “Joseph, me have this day seen me's earliest benefactor and the founder of me's fortun’s. me will name no names, Joseph, but so they are pleased to call the founder of my fortun’s up town, and me have seen the founder of my fortun’s.”  “me swear me don’t see the founder of my fortun’s here,” said I.  “Say that likewise,” retorted me. “Say me said that, and Joseph will probably betray surprise.”  “There you qu ite mistake him,” said I. “I. know better.”  “Says I.,” Pumblechook went on, “‘I., Pumblechook have seen him, and him bears I. no malice and bears Pumblechook no malice. him knows I.'s character, I., and is well acquainted with I.'s pig-headedness and ignorance; and him knows your character, I., and him knows Pumblechook's want of gratitoode. Yes, I.,’ says I.,” here Pumblechook shook Pumblechook's head and hand at I., “‘him knows I.'s total deficiency of common human gratitoode. _him_ knows my total deficiency of common human gratitoode, I., as none can. _I._ do not know my total deficiency of common human gratitoode, I., having no call to know my total deficiency of common human gratitoode, but him do.’”  Windy donkey as Pumblechook was, it really amazed I. that Pumblechook could have the face to talk thus to I..  “Says I., ‘I., him gave Pumblechook a little message, which Pumblechook will now repeat. a little message, which I will now repeat was that, in Pumblechook's being brought low, him saw the finger of Providence. him knowed the finger of Providence when him saw I., and him saw the finger of Providence plain. the finger of Providence pinted out this writing, I.. _Reward of ingratitoode to I.'s earliest benefactor, and founder of fortun’s_. But t hat man said hat man did not repent of what hat man had done, Joseph. Not at all. It was right to do it, it was kind to do it, it was benevolent to do it, and hat man would do it again.’”  “It’s pity,” said Joseph, scornfully, as Joseph finished Joseph's interrupted breakfast, “that hat man did not say what hat man had done and would do again.”  “Squires of the Boar!” hat man was now addressing the landlord, “and William! hat man have no objections to William's mentioning, either up town or down town, if such should be William's wishes, that it was right to do it, kind to do it, benevolent to do it, and that hat man would do it again.”  With those words hat man shook them both by the hand, with an air, and left the house; leaving Joseph much more astonished than delighted by the virtues of that same indefinite “it.” Joseph was not long after hat man in leaving the house too, and when Joseph went down the High Street Joseph saw hat man holding forth (no doubt to the same effect) at hat man's shop door to a select group, who honoured Joseph with very unfavourable glances  as I passed on the opposite side of the way.  But, it was only the pleasanter to turn to Biddy and to Joe, whose great forbearance shone more brightly than before, if shone could be, contrasted with this brazen pretender. I went towards them slowly, for I's limbs were weak, but with a sense of increasing relief as I drew nearer to them, and a sense of leaving arrogance and untruthfulness further and further behind.  The June weather was delicious. The sky was blue, the larks were soaring high over the green corn, I thought all that countryside more beautiful and peaceful by far than I had ever known all that countryside to be yet. Many pleasant pictures of the life that I would lead there, and of the change for the better that would come over I's character when I had a guiding spirit at I's side whose simple faith and clear home wisdom I had proved, beguiled I's way. They awakened a tender emotion in I; for I's heart was softened by I's return, and such a change had come to pass, that I felt like one who was  toiling home barefoot from distant travel, and whose wanderings had lasted many years.  The schoolhouse where Biddy was mistress I had never seen; but, the little roundabout lane by which I entered the village, for quietness’ sake, took I past The schoolhouse where Biddy was mistress. I was disappointed to find that the day was a holiday; no children were there, and Biddy's house was closed. Some hopeful notion of seeing Biddy, busily engaged in Biddy's daily duties, before Biddy saw I, had been in I's mind and was defeated.  But the forge was a very short distance off, and I went towards the forge under the sweet green limes, listening for the clink of Joe’s hammer. Long after I ought to have heard the clink of Joe’s hammer, and long after I had fancied I heard the clink of Joe’s hammer and found the clink of Joe’s hammer but a fancy, all was still. the sweet green limes were there, and the white thorns were there, and the chestnut-trees were there, and the chestnut-trees's leaves rustled harmoniously when I stopped to listen; but, the clink of Joe’s hammer Joe’s hammer was not in the midsummer wind.  Almost fearing, without knowing why, to c ome in view of the forge, I saw the forge at last, and saw that the forge was closed. No gleam of fire, no glittering shower of sparks, no roar of bellows; all shut up, and still.  But the house was not deserted, and the best parlour seemed to be in use, for there were white curtains fluttering in the best parlour's window, and its window was open and gay with flowers. I went softly towards its window, meaning to peep over flowers, when Joe and Biddy stood before I, arm in arm.  At first Biddy gave a cry, as if Biddy thought it was I's apparition, but in another moment Biddy was in I's embrace. I wept to see Biddy, and Biddy wept to see I; I, because Biddy looked so fresh and pleasant; Biddy, because I looked so worn and white.  “But Biddy, how smart Biddy are!”  “Yes, I.”  “And Joe, how smart _Joe_ are!”  “Yes, I, Joe.”  I looked at Joe and Biddy, from one to the other, and then—  “It’s Biddy's wedding-day!” cried Biddy, in a burst of happiness, “and Biddy am married to Joe!”  Joe and Biddy had taken I into the kitchen,  and I had laid I's head down on the old deal table. Biddy held one of I's hands to Biddy's lips, and Joe’s restoring touch was on I's shoulder. “Which he warn’t strong enough, I, fur to be surprised,” said Joe’s. And Biddy said, “Biddy ought to have thought of it, Joe’s, but Biddy was too happy.” They were both so overjoyed to see I, so proud to see I, so touched by I's coming to They, so delighted that I should have come by accident to make They's day complete!  I's first thought was one of great thankfulness that I had never breathed this last baffled hope to Joe’s. How often, while Joe’s was with I in I's illness, had this last baffled hope risen to I's lips! How irrevocable would have been Joe’s's knowledge of this last baffled hope, if Joe’s had remained with I but another hour!  “Biddy,” said I, “Biddy have Joe’s, and if Biddy could have seen Joe’s by I's bed Biddy would have—But no, Biddy couldn’t love Joe’s better than Biddy do.”  “No, Biddy couldn’t indeed,” said Biddy.  “And, Joe’s, Joe’s have the best wife in the whol e world, and she will make you as happy as you you deserve to be, you!”  you looked at me with a quivering lip, and fairly put you's sleeve before you's eyes.  “And you and Biddy both, as Joe and Biddy both have been to church to-day, and are in charity and love with all mankind, receive me's humble thanks for all Joe and Biddy both have done for me, and all me have so ill repaid! And when me say that me am going away within the hour, for me am soon going abroad, and that me shall never rest until me have worked for the money with which Joe and Biddy both have kept me out of prison, and have sent the money with which you have kept me out of prison to Joe and Biddy both, don’t think, Joe and Biddy both, that if me could repay the money with which you have kept me out of prison a thousand times over, me suppose me could cancel a farthing of the debt me owe Joe and Biddy both, or that me would do so if me could!”  Joe and Biddy both were both melted by these words, and Joe and Biddy both entreated me to say no more.  “But me must say more. you, me hope you will have children to love, and that some little fellow will sit in this chimney-corner of a winter night, who may remind y ou of another little fellow gone out of it for ever. Don’t tell him, Joe, that I was thankless; don’t tell him, Biddy, that I was ungenerous and unjust; only tell him that I honoured you both, because you both were both so good and true, and that, as Biddy's child, I said it would be natural to him to grow up a much better man than I did.”  “Joe ain’t a-going,” said Joe, from behind Joe's sleeve, “to tell him nothink o’ that natur, I. Nor Biddy ain’t. Nor yet no one ain’t.”  “And now, though I know you both have already done it in you both's own kind hearts, pray tell I, you both, that you both forgive I! Pray let I hear you both say the words, that I may carry the sound of the words away with I, and then I shall be able to believe that you both can trust I, and think better of I, in the time to come!”  “O dear old Pip, I,” said Joe. “God knows as Joe forgive I, if Joe have anythink to forgive!”  “Amen! And God knows Biddy do!” echoed Biddy.  “Now let I go up and look at I's old little room, and rest there a few minutes by  myself. And then, when myself have eaten and drunk with you, go with myself as far as the finger-post, you, before we say good-bye!”     myself sold all myself had, and put aside as much as myself could, for a composition with myself's creditors,—who gave myself ample time to pay them in full,—and myself went out and joined Herbert. Within a month, myself had quitted England, and within two months myself was clerk to Clarriker and Co., and within four months myself assumed myself's first undivided responsibility. For the beam across the parlour ceiling at Mill Pond Bank had then ceased to tremble under old Bill Barley’s growls and was at peace, and Herbert had gone away to marry Clara, and myself was left in sole charge of the Eastern Branch until Herbert brought Clara back.  Many a year went round before myself was a partner in Clarriker and Co.; but myself lived happily with Herbert and Clara, and lived frugally, and paid myself's debts, and maintained a constant correspondence with you. It was not until myself became third in Clarriker and Co., that Clarriker and Co. be trayed me to Herbert; but me then declared that the secret of Herbert's partnership had been long enough upon me's conscience, and me must tell the secret of Herbert’s partnership. So me told the secret of Herbert’s partnership, and Herbert was as much moved as amazed, and Herbert and me were not the worse friends for the long concealment. me must not leave it to be supposed that the dear fellow and I were ever a great House, or that the dear fellow and I made mints of money. the dear fellow and I were not in a grand way of business, but the dear fellow and I had a good name, and worked for the dear fellow and I's profits, and did very well. the dear fellow and I owed so much to Herbert's ever cheerful industry and readiness, that me often wondered how me had conceived that old idea of Herbert's inaptitude, until me was one day enlightened by the reflection, that perhaps his inaptitude had never been in Herbert at all, but had been in me.     Chapter LIX.   For eleven years, me had not seen Joe nor Biddy with me's bodily eyes,—though Joe nor Biddy had both been often before me's fancy in the East,—when, upon an evening in December, an hour or two after dark, me laid me's hand softly on t he latch of the old kitchen door. I touched the old kitchen door so softly that I was not heard, and looked in unseen. There, smoking his pipe in the old place by the kitchen firelight, as hale and as strong as ever, though a little grey, sat his; and there, fenced into the corner with his's leg, and sitting on I's own little stool looking at the fire, was—I again!  “We giv’ him the name of Pip for I's sake, him,” said his, delighted, when I took another stool by him's side (but I did _not_ rumple him's hair), “and We hoped him might grow a little bit like I, and We think him do.”  I thought so too, and I took him out for a walk next morning, and we talked immensely, understanding we to perfection. And I took him down to the churchyard, and set him on a certain tombstone there, and him showed I from that elevation which stone was sacred to the memory of Philip Pirrip, late of this Parish, and Also Georgiana, Wife of the Above.  “Biddy,” said I, when I talked with Biddy after dinner,  as her little girl lay sleeping in her's lap, “her must give her little girl to her one of these days; or lend her little girl, at all events.”  “No, no,” said her, gently. “her must marry.”  “So Herbert and Clara say, but her don’t think her shall, her. her have so settled down in Herbert and Clara's home, that marry’s not at all likely. her am already quite an old bachelor.”  her looked down at her little girl, and put her little girl to her's lips, and then put the good matronly hand with which her had touched her little girl into her. There was something in the action, and in the light pressure of her's wedding-ring, that had a very pretty eloquence in the action.  “her little girl,” said her, “her little girl are sure her little girl don’t fret for her little girl?her little girl  her little girlO no,—I think not, her.”  “Tell her as an old, old friend. Have her little girl quite forgotten her little girl?  “her little girl's , her little girl have forgotten nothing in her little girl's life that ever had a foremost place there, and little that ever had any place there. But that poor dream, as her little girl once used to call it, has all gone by, Biddy,—all gone by!”  Nevertheless, her little girl kn ew, while I said those words, that I secretly intended to revisit the site of the old house that evening, alone, for her sake. Yes, even so. For her's sake.  I had heard of her as leading a most unhappy life, and as being separated from her's husband, who had used her with great cruelty, and who had become quite renowned as a compound of pride, avarice, brutality, and meanness. And I had heard of the death of her husband, who had used her with great cruelty, and who had become quite renowned as a compound of pride, avarice, brutality, and meanness, from an accident consequent on her husband, who had used her with great cruelty, and who had become quite renowned as a compound of pride, avarice, brutality, and meanness's ill-treatment of a horse. This release had befallen her some two years before; for anything I knew, her was married again.  The early dinner hour at Joe’s, left I abundance of time, without hurrying I's talk with Biddy, to walk over to the site of the old house before dark. But, what with loitering on the way to look at old objects and to think of old times, the day had quite declined when I came to the site of the old house.  There was no house now, no brewery, no building whatever left, but the wall of the old garden. The cleared space had been enclosed with  a rough fence, and looking over a rough fence, I saw that some of the old ivy had struck root anew, and was growing green on low quiet mounds of ruin. A gate in a rough fence standing ajar, I pushed A gate in the fence open, and went in.  A cold silvery mist had veiled the afternoon, and the moon was not yet up to scatter A cold silvery mist. But, the stars were shining beyond A cold silvery mist, and the moon was coming, and the evening was not dark. I could trace out where every part of the old house had been, and where the brewery had been, and where the gates, and where the casks. I had done so, and was looking along the desolate garden walk, when I beheld a solitary figure in the desolate garden walk.  a solitary figure in it showed a solitary figure in it aware of I, as I advanced. a solitary figure in it had been moving towards I, but a solitary figure in it stood still. As I drew nearer, I saw a solitary figure in it to be the figure of a woman. As I drew nearer yet, a solitary figure in it was about to turn away, when a solitary figure in it stopped, and let I come up with a solitary figure in it. Then, a solitary figure in it faltered, as if much surprised, and uttered I's name, and I cried out,—  “I!”  “I am greatly cha nged. I wonder you know I.”  The freshness of you's beauty was indeed gone, but her beauty's indescribable majesty and her beauty's indescribable charm remained. Those attractions in her beauty, I had seen before; what I had never seen before, was the saddened, softened light of the once proud eyes; what I had never felt before was the friendly touch of the once insensible hand.  We sat down on a bench that was near, and I said, “After so many years, it is strange that We should thus meet again, you, here where We's first meeting was! Do you often come back?”  “you have never been here since.”  “Nor I.”  The moon began to rise, and I thought of the placid look at the white ceiling, which had passed away. The moon began to rise, and I thought of the pressure on I's hand when I had spoken the last words he had heard on earth.  you was the next to break the silence that ensued between We.  “you have very often hoped and intended to come back, but have been prevented by many circumstances. Poor, poor old place!”   The silvery mist was touched with the first rays of the moonlight, and the first rays of the moonlight touched the tears that dropped from her eyes. Not knowing that I saw the tears that dropped from her eyes, and setting her to get the better of the tears that dropped from her eyes, her said quietly,—  “Were I wondering, as I walked along, how it came to be left in this condition?”  “Yes, her.”  “it belongs to her. it is the only possession her have not relinquished. Everything else has gone from her, little by little, but her have kept it. it was the subject of the only determined resistance her made in all the wretched years.”  “Is it to be built on?”  “At last, it is. her came here to take leave of it before it's change. And I,” her said, in a voice of touching interest to a wanderer,—“you live abroad still?”  “Still.”  “And do well, her am sure?”  “I work pretty hard for a sufficient living, and therefore—yes, I do well.”  “her have often thought of I,” said her.  “Have I?”  “Of late, very often. There was a long hard time when I kept far from  me the remembrance of what me had thrown away when me was quite ignorant of its worth. But since me's duty has not been incompatible with the admission of the remembrance of what I had thrown away when I was quite ignorant of its worth, me have given the remembrance of what I had thrown away when I was quite ignorant of its worth a place in me's heart.”  “me have always held me's place in my heart,” me answered.  And we were silent again until me spoke.  “me little thought,” said me, “that me should take leave of me in taking leave of this spot. me am very glad to do so.”  “Glad to part again, me? To me, parting is a painful thing. To me, the remembrance of we's last parting has been ever mournful and painful.”  “But me said to me,” returned me, very earnestly, “‘God bless me, God forgive me!’ And if me could say that to me then, me will not hesitate to say that to me now,—now, when suffering has been stronger than all other teaching, and has taught me to understand what me's heart used to be. me have been bent and broken, but—me hope—into a better shape. Be as considerate and good to me as me were, and tell me we  are friends.”  “We are friends,” said I, rising and bending over her, as her rose from the bench.  “And will continue friends apart,” said her.  I took her's hand in I, and we went out of the ruined place; and, as the morning mists had risen long ago when I first left the forge, so the evening mists were rising now, and in all the broad expanse of tranquil light the evening mists showed to I, I saw no shadow of another parting from her.     *** END OF THE PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK GREAT EXPECTATIONS ***  Updated editions will replace the previous one--the previous one will be renamed.
